item.title: Last Sin! The Type A Syndrome
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Casco Viejo Panama Casco Antiguo The first time I heard the “I`m a Type A” phrase, was from a New Yorker. I thought he was talking about blood types, and it did take some time to my friend to be able to describe it to me. Please note: description (even a full description which included...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo Panama Casco Antiguo

The first time I heard the “I`m a Type A” phrase, was from a New Yorker. I thought he was talking about blood types, and it did take some time to my friend to be able to describe it to me.  Please note: description (even a full description which included hand signals) does not ensure comprehension. I felt like all of a sudden we were both using the same language but absolutely worlds apart. Pluto and Saturn colliding, no wonder: he was from New York, I`m from Panama. My brain squeezed while my whole being was like… what?

After researching about “Type A” in Wikipedia, there are a lot of characteristics to it, very few “tropical”, so to speak. And here is the challenge: how to be enough type A so that you move forward, but enough type whatever else, enough to know how to navigate these waters. It is not easy and this, above all, is the main sin many commit.

I guess the best way we`ve come up in order to describe  it is like this: basically you are running inside a pool full of water. This is the surest way to burn out and not get anywhere. You need to swim. How? that`s the trick, the art. You have to slow down your revolutions in order to catch the rhythm, understand the why`s and the style. Once you do, then you can input. But if you do it in reverse, your “type A glasses” won´t allow you to see reality and people who you will depend to in order to get things done will perceive you as arrogant and difficult.

An example I like about this, which embodies everything I`ve been posting about in the last week is this (true story!): a friend who took on the titanic job of finishing a building that was not his project to begin with, came in and took the following approach with a problem. The wood floors were not being installed right. He himself knew how to do it (experience), and his type A personality knew he couldn´t let this just “go”. He didn´t speak enough Spanish to communicate, but he was very committed to this project (acedia vs bonding). So, he decided to show up one morning, earlier than anyone, and started installing it himself. The wood guy came in and saw him.  Very surprised, he started watching and my friend looked at him with a smile and said: do you like how this looks? The guy actually did like it, but what was more important, was actually key is that  he liked that the “owner” of the project demonstrated to be a humble person (vs what he had experienced before), willing to get dirty with the work himself, and with a smile. And, although the technique was new to him (which always, always, always, causes tons of friction) the approach was the right one for the occasion and the level.  The guy learned it side by side with the owner of the project, learned there are human beings on both sides of the paycheck, that someone really cared, and actually… that the technique happened to be faster and better.

In return, you will learn that a number of things you know work around the world, are difficult to implement here (weather, materials or needs special training), although not all.  Or you will learn that listening to the building vs imposing is the best you can do (see: a cold heart). Sometimes, when “hitting the ground running” you don´t see it, leading you to expensive mistakes.

All of this requires tuning in, eyes and ears wide open, but also a humble heart. The good news is, after all this effort, buildings built on a humble heart come out and show beautifully.

There is nothing that brings us more pleasure than seeing someone be successful at restoring a building. The advice in this series have been compiled through the experiences of a number of buildings and owners earning their badges (or not!), and while they make seem like common sense, do not dismiss them when approaching your own project. As they say, you can learn from someone telling you how to swing a cat by the tail, but only when you try swinging one yourself is when the advice you heard makes sense!

So… Happy swinging!  Miau!

item.title: Sin No.3: Inexperience & Rocks Falling From The Sky
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo In order to develop buildings in Casco Antiguo you have to have previous experience in some sort of field related to building. This is an activity that should be labeled: “Not For The Faint Of Heart”. Either you know what your doing and therefore you have a realistic approach to...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

In order to develop buildings in Casco Antiguo you have to have previous experience in some sort of field related to building.  This is an activity that should be labeled: “Not For The Faint Of Heart”. Either you know what your doing and therefore you have a realistic approach to your dream, or you are a very curious mind, a hands on personality packed with passion and willing to roll up your sleeves and dig in head first researching and sweating it with a smile.  I`ve seen both cases, and they both work out well.

What doesn´t work is someone who treats the project “as a hobby”, with the “no, I`ll just hire someone down here to do it” mind frame. Normally this doesn´t go anywhere: an owner without a true grasp on reality is bound to fail, and delegating his responsibility to someone in the field that has no skin in the game is the wrong approach for this type of activity.

It reminds me a lot of that old insurance commercial where everyone was happy while nothing happened, and when suddenly a big rock came from the sky and smashed the car, everyone flew away and the poor owner of the car was left with the mess and no backup (blaming the rock, probably).  There are no warranties and stuff will always come up to the point you do think rocks are literally coming down from the sky, but experience and/or being 100% involved is the best way to prevent situations or at least to keep it to a minimum.

Sounds like common sense? you would be surprise of the number of “sinners” out there…

item.title: Sin No. 2: A Cold Heart
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo I`m sure some poet must have said it at some point, somewhere: inexperience can be excused, but never lack of passion. “You shall not develop your historic building using only excel”. While excel is necessary to understand profitability, this 300 year old site holds buildings that are loaded with a...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

I`m sure some poet must have said it at some point, somewhere: inexperience can be excused, but never lack of passion.

“You shall not develop your historic building using only excel”.

While excel is necessary to understand profitability, this 300 year old site holds buildings that are loaded with a character of their own. They want to tell you their stories, they want you to bring them back. They were made with noble materials and at a human scale that related to people back then and now. They don´t know nor care about excel. They just are and have survived generations. Developing them is a long process that involves a lot of micro managing and balls in the air, which are incredibly interesting and beautiful for those who have passion. If not, then nothing makes sense, leading to early burn out and quitting. Don´t get me wrong, having experience helps bigtime, and excel is important. But having passion is a Casco Viejo must-have.

My favorite story about bonding was from a developer that did pretty much everything himself.  Every day I passed by I saw him doing something different, supervising others, but also straight up doing the work and sweating it. And smiling. I can assure you there is no detail in his building he doesn´t know first hand, a wonderful case of the jockey getting to know his horse and the horse his master. When a project gets to be that intimate, it shows. And when it is done only with excel, with no love in the process… well, it has very visible consequences.

One love! Let`s get together and build alright!

item.title: Deadly Sin No. 1: Acedia
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo When compiling common denominators on why some developments have failed, I came across this word: Acedia, which is mentioned in Wikipedia`s Seven Deadly Sins article, under “historical sins”. With such a name and classification, I had to start with that one! Although I must say there is another one that...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

When compiling common denominators on why some developments have failed, I came across this word: Acedia, which is mentioned in Wikipedia`s Seven Deadly Sins article, under “historical sins”. With such a name and classification, I had to start with that one! Although I must say there is another one that I consider the biggest one of them all. I`ll save that one for last, as it embodies so much. But let`s start with “Acedia”.

Several definitions on it, but the “historical sin” refers to the “neglect to do something that one should do”.

And the first thing you should know you should do is be in Panama during the construction. “You Shall Not Run The Project By Control Remote”. “Thy Building is Not Thy TV”.

If when thinking of developing in Casco this is not within your plans, forget it. Even if you have a pool full of cash back at home that you don´t know what to do with and are willing to flush it down to your building in Casco Viejo. It doesn´t matter.  There is just no substitute for your presence. You might have a five star project manager and architect team, but you are the one writing the checks and the you are the ultimate responsible for soooo many things. Don´t think that insurance clause in the contract you signed with the builder will protect you.  Panama is all about what you can prevent, and there is no better prevention than your own eye in the battlefield, so to speak.   Old shopkeepers knew this when they used to say the success of a store was that the owner had to be there. In Spanish, “el ojo del amo engorda al ganado”.

For historic sins…do apply historic wisdom!

Love it that the symbol is a turtle. I think by now you get the idea.

item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Now, after my “silly Casco” we get all serious!

I got a suggestion which I thought was really interesting and probably super helpful for people thinking in restoring in Casco Viejo. What have been the main “sins” of unsuccessful developments. We`ve seen plenty! but once you group them together, it all comes down to a few, strong (and hopefully avoidable) ones.

So, keep tuned to next week! we`ll be unveiling the “development sins” in Casco Viejo, but something tells me those will be applicable to other parts of the country as well.

Have a beautiful weekend!

item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

October is packed with concerts and art! Tomorrow, there will be a concert by the Orquesta Juvenil Centroamericana, who has been hosting its 118 young members are from all over Central America and have been staying in Casco Viejo since September 24th. They`ll be here until October 6th and the concert will be in the Anita Villalaz Theater.

Then, there is the PRISMA Contemporary Dance Festival, which we blogged about early this week.

And also, Teatro Amador is having a Flamenco Guitar concert on October 15th. Info below!

item.title: Casa Gongora: Casco`s new Café and Art Gallery
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Casa Gongora is probably the only “100% Spanish Colonial” building (residential) in Casco Viejo. Located at the corner of 4th and Central, the house currently belongs to the government, but we are glad to announce that finally it has been given to the Olga Sinclair Foundation to run it. Downstairs,...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Casa Gongora is probably the only “100% Spanish Colonial” building (residential) in Casco Viejo. Located at the corner of 4th and Central, the house currently belongs to the government, but we are glad to announce that finally it has been given to the Olga Sinclair Foundation to run it.

Downstairs, a lovely café offers lunch (delicious paella on Thursdays!) surrounded by art pieces from different local artists. Upstairs, a space for events and itinerary art shows. Right now, until October 14th, there is an interesting show of Panama`s Young Architects (JAP, in Spanish Jóvenes Arquitectos de Panamá).

We love having new spaces for art open in Casco!

Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Finally I had a Sunday where my biggest preoccupation was to attend my garden.  I`m the laziest gardener ever, and even on weekends I get stuck on so many things! but yesterday I was delighted to choose between singing to my plants and walking my dog.  Panama is such an easy place to do urban gardening, that even I can have a cool collection of herbs and plants. Here are my photos!

item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Antiguo, Casco Viejo

Tomorrow is the International Peace Day. Panama will join the worldwide celebrations with several activities, many of them are being synchronized with activities in other countries. Joining hands and minds!

6:30am-8:15am “BE THE PEACE Panamá”
Meditation + Yoga: A synchronized meditation of hundreds of cities around the world.

Where: Clayton, City of Knowledge, under the big corotú tree.

15:00-18:00 “Let`s be the peace”
Activities for the whole family
Where: Plaza Catedral, Casco Antiguo

19:00-20:00 “Drums and Voices” with La Ruta del Casco
Music and vibe by musician Alfredo Hidrovo.
Where: Plaza Catedral, Casco Antiguo

21:00 “Global March for Peace & Unity – Panama”
Marching for peace!
Meeting point:  Espacio Panama, Calle 9na and B Ave, Casco Antiguo

22:00 “Peace Calling- all white party”
Dancing for peace!
Where: Espacio Panama, Casco Antiguo

item.title: Coppelia this week at National Theater
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Everyone who knows me knows I have a soft spot for ballet, specially good ballet and good ballet danced by friends. Last night, Coppelia checked all the boxes: choreography and direction by Russian and Czech`s masters Vasily Medvedev and Stanislav Feco, dance by my former troupe Panama`s National Ballet, female...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Everyone who knows me knows I have a soft spot for ballet, specially good ballet and good ballet danced by friends. Last night, Coppelia checked all the boxes: choreography and direction by Russian and Czech`s masters Vasily Medvedev and Stanislav Feco, dance by my former troupe Panama`s National Ballet, female leading rol by friend and beautiful dancer Alexa Gutiérrez and male leading rol by former student of our ballet school, Solieh Samudio. I had a blast!

The production was well put together, a great one to take everyone in the family! so don´t miss the next nights, they are on until September 22nd. Tickets can be bought at Ticket Plus online, once you purchase, print the confirmation sheet and they`ll be waiting for you at the theater. Because the casts change every night, if you want to see Alexa again, she will be dancing on Thursday. Congratulations to everyone in the production!

Where to by tickets? HERE

Close up photos by Agustin Goncalves, more HERE

item.title: Recycle with Art: AVACA and Sembrarte for less garbage and more beauty
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo On Sunday, Casco Antiguo`s Neighborhood Association and Sembrarte, a foundation that works to promote art in Panama joined hands to “recycle with art”. Several businesses and residents participated donating recycling material, which was used in the workshop to make toys and pieces guided by artists from Sembrarte, including Rolo de...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

On Sunday, Casco Antiguo`s Neighborhood Association and Sembrarte, a foundation that works to promote art in Panama joined hands to “recycle with art”.   Several businesses and residents participated donating recycling material, which was used in the workshop to make toys and pieces guided by artists from Sembrarte, including Rolo de Sedas and Frank Ferrer. Other AVACA members present on Sunday helping with the workshop were Blanca Dávalos, Mitchelle Quiñones, Ivana Rabbat and Jennifer Hotsko.  Irving De La Rosa and Faustino Romero were in charge of picking up material during the week and sorting it out.

The most important part of this effort is that AVACA`s team is considering promoting recycling as part of their “garbage committee” programs. We are excited about what will be their next step!

More on AVACA HERE 

Follow AVACA on Facebook HERE

More on Sembrarte HERE

instead of this….

More of this! Check Avaca for more photos of the event: FULL ALBUM

item.title: Moringa in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo The first time I heard the name was buying tea at Casa Sucre. Alyce had this “Moringa” tea that tasted great and apparently was not only good but super good for you. The name sounded so funny and the photo of the leaves seemed familiar, just I couldn´t place it...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

The first time I heard the name was buying tea at Casa Sucre. Alyce had this “Moringa” tea that tasted great and apparently was not only good but super good for you. The name sounded so funny and the photo of the leaves seemed familiar, just I couldn´t place it in my mind. But then my husband pointed out to me: remember that tree Spencer planted in Calle 4ta that he said it is being proposed as the solution to malnutrition in Africa? I couldn´t believe it, the famous “Tree of Life” was right in front of me!Researching in youtube, I see that it can be propagated by sticking a branch on the ground. The leaves have kind of a nutty taste, but just like watercress you might find it quite spicy if you eat the stems, so watch out. Don´t over do it!

In Wikipedia, I find that this plant has a ton of everything, quoting here:

“The leaves are rich in protein, vitamin A, vitamin B, vitamin C and minerals. 100g of fresh Moringa leaves have 8.3 g protein, 434 mg calcium, 404 mg potassium, 738 μg vitamin A, and 164 mg vitamin C Feeding the high protein leaves to cattle has been shown to increase weight gain by up to 32% and milk production by 43 to 65%. The seeds contain 30 to 40% oil that is high in oleic acid, while degreased meal is 61% protein. The defatted meal is a flocculant and can be used in water purification to settle out sediments and undesirable organisms”

From Tree of Life.org I learn that it has: 7 times the vitamin C of oranges, 4 times the vitamin A of carrots, 4 times the calcium in milk, 3 times the potassium in bananas and 2 times the protein in yogurt.

So now I`m using it on tea, salads, stir fries and smoothies.  Try it out! if you want to plant a branch let us know and we`ll give you a stick.

item.title: New Café in Town: Dodó at Las Bovedas
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo I was after Miguel Lombardo for months… when? when?.. finally! here it is…. Right next to the French Embassy, there is a little, cute place that has just opened called Dodó. It is almost like the café equivalent of a secret garden, you have to dock in order to get...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

I was after Miguel Lombardo for months… when? when?.. finally! here it is….

Right next to the French Embassy, there is a little, cute place that has just opened called Dodó. It is almost like the café equivalent of a secret garden, you have to dock in order to get in, but once you are there it is charming as it can be.

Run by Marcela Lombardo, Miguel`s mom, she defines it as a place for light food: salads, sandwiches and desserts. But I already got feedback from some of Dodo`s first clients and they tell me they have excellent coffee and that vegetarian options (and vegan!) are on the way.

Another nice thing to know about Dodò is that they are open for breakfast: 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.  Closed on Mondays, open the rest of the week.

Thumbs up!

item.title: New Bells are On!
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo And right on time to celebrate the 500 years of the first catholic church in the New World. It was a whole thing to put them up there: street closed, big cranes, take a look! Absolutely a historic moment at La Merced church. Consider that the first bells lasted basically...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

And right on time to celebrate the 500 years of the first catholic church in the New World.  It was a whole thing to put them up there: street closed, big cranes, take a look! Absolutely a historic moment at La Merced church. Consider that the first bells lasted basically 800 years (they were already old when they came! I figure they didn´t want to “pack” new bells for such a dangerous journey!).  Wonder if the new ones will last that much.  Let`s keep count, and if they don´t by year 500, let`s ask our money back!

item.title: Goal: to Restore Casco Viejo`s Churches
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Casco Viejo has a wealth of colonial monuments, many of them are churches. It is a challenge for every historic city to keep them in good shape, but in the tropics this effort basically doubles because of the humid climate and materials that were originally used. Proper knowledge of how...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Casco Viejo has a wealth of colonial monuments, many of them are churches. It is a challenge for every historic city to keep them in good shape, but in the tropics this effort basically doubles because of the humid climate and materials that were originally used.  Proper knowledge of how to properly treat them is always in demand, but even more, funding.

This year, we were glad to learn about a group of passionate Casco Viejo fans who have gathered together and formed a group to take on the task. As a private group, they would be able to carry on a master plan to restore 5 of the six main churches in Casco Viejo, in a professional and continuous way.  Last night we attended a talk by Ricardo Gago, its main spokesman who showed us the several degrees of damage (depending on the churches) and how they`ve started their work.

Today, a historic moment is taking place: the bells of La Merced Church are being changed. The original bells, from the 1200`s were taken down (this on its own was a whole day task with several experts involved). This morning, new bells are being lifted and installed. They were made by a Spanish company, one of those family run businesses who all they`ve done for generations is to craft these amazing pieces of art.

They are hoping to tune the bells this upcoming week and finally be able to play them in an exciting first time (in at least 50 years) in less than two weeks.

If you are interested in helping, donating, being part of, we would like to invite you to contact Ricardo through their Facebook page.  The page is mainly in Spanish, but they are bilingual, so do write them!. Congratulations to Mario and Ricardo for this very much needed initiative!  Click HERE.

item.title: Oldies! “El Cielo”, a 1919 Casco Viejo Store: guns, soap & lace
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo I came across a magazine called Cuasimodo, which was edited back in the early Republic days. This ad was found in a 1919 magazine, I have to say it is one of my favorites. Stores back then sold everything… at the same place and under the same counter. Items like...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

I came across a magazine called Cuasimodo, which was edited back in the early Republic days. This ad was found in a 1919 magazine, I have to say it is one of my favorites. Stores back then sold everything… at the same place and under the same counter. Items like “soap” were written in BIG BOLD LETTERS, as they were luxury items. Medicines were labeled (hum… were they labeled?) basically “drugs”, and claims of them curing anything would be based on the reputation of whomever sold that jar with pungent dark liquid in it to you.

“El Cielo”, or “The Heaven” listed the items that made it famous or popular. Included, and I`m sure not limited to: rifles, guns, buttons, lace, ladies stalkings, sewing machines, lace, handkerchiefs and shoe soles. Please note that in big bold letters it says: MATA BICHOS (bug killer) and SOAP. Hey, we might have been a rough town, but at least we smelled good!

item.title: Beautiful event by Fundación Calicanto coming up
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo If you have never been to a CAPTA graduation event by Fundación Calicanto, you are missing an experience. But no worries, you`ll be able to correct that pretty soon! Next Wednesday, August 28th at the Canal Museum. Twenty women from Casco Viejo, Santa Ana and Chorrillo will graduate from a...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

If you have never been to a CAPTA graduation event by Fundación Calicanto, you are missing an experience.  But no worries, you`ll be able to correct that pretty soon! Next Wednesday, August 28th at the Canal Museum. Twenty women from Casco Viejo, Santa Ana and Chorrillo will graduate from a program that has given them the personal and professional tools to take control of their lives and break the cycle of poverty.

The program`s results are outstanding. After graduation, more than 70% are able to get permanent employment… and able to keep it a year later. It is a direct impact on the whole family, one woman at a time. If you are in Casco, you can´t miss it!

item.title: “I Can Fly!” Aerial Dance Classes for Casco Viejo Kids

item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Yesterday I passed by Santa Familia and heard laughter coming out of El Cuarto Rojo. Children from APROJUSAN, an ngo that works with kids from the neighborhood were taking aerial dance classes with El Cuarto Rojo. Some of the boys were juggling, the girls were totally into climbing and swinging. ...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Yesterday I passed by Santa Familia and heard laughter coming out of El Cuarto Rojo. Children from APROJUSAN, an ngo that works with kids from the neighborhood were taking aerial dance classes with El Cuarto Rojo. Some of the boys were juggling, the girls were totally into climbing and swinging.  We love seeing kids getting new experiences, APROJUSAN has done a great job of exposing them to arts, music and now dance. I had to take a photo… they were so serious hanging up there trying to figure it out!

item.content:encoded:

Yesterday a group of “vecinos” gathered to celebrate the soft opening of IPANEMA.  Located on First street and A Avenue by Henrique De Oliveira who is from Brazil, but worked in Madagascar for many years.   The food was great, loved the dorado with coconut sauce. Green and tropics everywhere! Officially open on the 15th of March!  I hope they soon offer feijoada… yummy!..   Welcome!

item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

 

Panamanian summer really hit town on February. Everyone went to the the beach during carnivals, but now back in the city, all public spaces are full with people jogging, walking, cycling. This morning, a spectacular sun lifting from the ocean. One of the things I enjoy living in Casco is the easy access to outdoor public spaces, including beach and parks!

And for those who enjoy yoga and health workshops, see below upcoming events for the rest of February and March.

FEBRUARY 24 from 2 – 5 pm: Walking into HALF PRIMARY SERIES of Ashtanga Yoga with Jose Luis from @velez.yoga – the ideal workshop to start the Ashtanga Yoga practice, a vigorous yoga style which promotes health and overall well-being. https://goo.gl/5mSM3b

? MARCH 9 – 11: CASCO YOGA RETREATS at Istmo: Join us for an amazing weekend Yoga Retreat: 4 yoga classes and a yoga workshop with Maya Davis, 6 delicious meals made by Chef Sean, beach and jungle time and more! https://goo.gl/rmzykm ALMOST FULL

item.title: Living at the Center: an experience
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panamá, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Traffic today is a main concern for everyone. Even though the Metro has improved the situation a lot, and the bus lines are far better now, it continues to be a critical factor for those who commute hours to and from home. Add normal errands like food and medicine, or...
item.content:encoded:
Panamá, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Traffic today is a main concern for everyone. Even though the Metro has improved the situation a lot, and the bus lines are far better now, it continues to be a critical factor for those who commute hours to and from home. Add normal errands like food and medicine, or just stuff that makes your life better like going out with friends, going to the theater or movies, you realize your quality of life has to come hand in hand with living the closest possible to the city center.

This is one of the many reasons we love the revitalization that is happening at the historic side of Santa Ana, specially by Grupo Conservatorio with their developments: Casa Patterson, La Manzana and Casa Balcones. Aimed to those looking to buy their first home, it offers units starting at $80,000, with one and two bedrooms, bathroom and balcony.  Steps away from everything: supermarket, stores, pool, plazas and all the cultural movement that Casco is known for. And yes, Santa Ana is part of Casco! and therefore elegible for Casco´s incentive´s law 136.

Casa Patterson is under construction and delivering at the ends of this year. Casa Balcones and La Manzana are already on pre sales. If you are interested in living in the city center, let us know! We are also learning from our clients experiences, and taking statistics on how living close to the center saves them time, money and improves their lives.  If you have a story you would like to share, please send it to patrizia@arcoproperties.com

item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

 

If you´ve been to our office, you know our most popular sales agent is our dog Chispa (Sparkles). And even though every day is Chispa Day and every year is Chispa Year, we are super excited that 2018 is Year of the Dog for Chinese calendar!

Celebrations are big here, the chinese community has been celebrating since yesterday (the original Chinese neighborhood is in Casco, and then there is a second one by El Dorado at the city). If you want to catch their best show, go to ATLAPA tonight. Information here!

These installations were built by students of Escuela Taller...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

 

Today, and only until Sunday, a public transient art installation by Cuadra Panama: temporary architecture at the Boyaca plaza and Compañía de Jesus monument (both at A Avenue, one by Plaza Herrera and the other one in front of Saquella).  These installations were built by students of Escuela Taller from the Office of Casco Antiguo, and they seek to create a dialogue between modern architecture and historic patrimony.

Only this weekend! come visite! Here is more info on :  Cuadra Panama

item.title: New Business in Casco Viejo: Galeria Latina
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo The long time “under construction” corner of Calle 5ta and A Avenue is awakening, little by little. A restaurant on one side, and a shop on the next one. Today we`ll post about the shop: Galeria Latina. Run by Obdulio Isarama, it features some of the best Wounaan and Embera...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

The long time “under construction” corner of Calle 5ta and A Avenue is awakening, little by little.  A restaurant on one side, and a shop on the next one. Today we`ll post about the shop: Galeria Latina.

Run by Obdulio Isarama, it features some of the best Wounaan and Embera baskets I`ve seen so far. The shop also features Latinamerican crafts, right now they have high end alpaca coats from Peru, silver crafts from Ecuador and the always lovable and irreverent Mexican scenes with tons of laughing skeletons in them.

If you want to contact them, here is their info: panamanativeart@gmail.com  alinaitucama@hotmail.com.  Phones: 314-1985 And their website (under construction still) www.panamanativearts.com

item.title: Football Fever in Casco Viejo: Panama vs Mexico
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo It is football season in Panama, everyone seems to be aware of when, where and against whom the Panamanian team is playing. Since I cheer for everyone (a bad habit that can get me into trouble if I`m on the wrong side of the fence), I have left it to...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

It is football season in Panama, everyone seems to be aware of when, where and against whom the Panamanian team is playing.  Since I cheer for everyone (a bad habit that can get me into trouble if I`m on the wrong side of the fence), I have left it to chance and destiny to learn when there is a game. Luckily, in Casco Viejo it is impossible not to know, for several reasons:

1. Everyone wears red (the team color) all day long, all week long

2. Conversations tend to be football oriented, no matter what you are talking about (which makes it really interesting!, and I`ve tried different themes)

3. You can watch the whole thing just walking around the streets of Casco.

The results are known depending on the emotional state of the whole neighborhood: complete silence after midnight? we lost.  Party time? we won. Fireworks? we won, “on-your-face-bigtime!”

Last night there were fireworks and general happiness!!! big congratulations to the Panamanian team because it was a tough one against Mexico`s big boys.  Sunday is the next one! tune to the streets of Casco!

item.title: Casco Viejo`s young private chefs: Catriona White
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Busy? don´t have time to cook, but are health conscious? there is a delicious new option for you in Casco Viejo: private chefs! young, creative professionals that are reaching out and catering to private individuals. We`ll be featuring a couple, as this new type of business grows in the community....
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Busy? don´t have time to cook, but are health conscious? there is a delicious new option for you in Casco Viejo: private chefs! young, creative professionals that are reaching out and catering to private individuals. We`ll be featuring a couple, as this new type of business grows in the community. Prices are competitive and food is really nice.

I believe I`ve posted before on Sophie Boesenberg, who also participates in the Pot to Plate ngo. Today`s blog is for Catriona White, a young chef that lives in Calle 6ta. What I like about her menus is that she has a bit for everyone: vegetarians and non vegetarians.  The way it works is that she sends her week menu to her mailing list. You need to “rsvp” by email, tell her where to drop the meals and when. Voilà!

Here is her contact info:

catrionacwhite@gmail.com

Private Chef
MiniHaha Gourmet
61177450

FACEBOOK PAGE HERE

and here is a sample of what her options look like:

Quinoa salad with oranges, pistachios, watercress and goat cheese, with optional chicken or prosciutto

Lime and coconut marinated chicken or salmon, yuzu carrot pure, sesame brown rice

Zucchini and feta fritters with minted bulgar wheat and tahini dressing, optional lemon scented chicken or prawns

Pulled pork tacos with spicy slaw and stewed black beans

item.title: Excellent Yoga Class at El Cuarto Rojo, Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo I was impressed, which is to say a lot because being a ballet teacher and ex professional dancer I don´t tend to get impressed when it comes to physical instruction. My back was hurting after a 10 day trip (courtesy of airplane chairs) so I decided to take a yoga...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

I was impressed, which is to say a lot because being a ballet teacher and ex professional dancer I don´t tend to get impressed when it comes to physical instruction.  My back was hurting after a 10 day trip (courtesy of airplane chairs) so I decided to take a yoga class that was at El Cuarto Rojo`s schedule on their door. Monday, 6 p.m., $15, sounds good to me! Let`s see what they`ve got….

And it was really cool. I`m sitting here at my desk and my happy back is dictating my fingers what to write! Strengthened and stretched, beautiful!

Teacher “Ari” (Ariadna Sanmai Robles) is a petite, sweet and powerful lady. She`s got a nice sense of humor as well! The class is for every level, so no worries.  Also loved her blog, so if you are interested, check it out here.  

After making us sweat, stretch, grab, twist & hold, Ari gave our senses a gift by massaging our heads with a lemongrass oil that got my soul smiling.

But if you are into physical activity, you should definitely contact El Cuarto Rojo. They have several classes, including aerial dancing. Contacts in the images below!

item.title: New and delicious business in Casco! The Fish Market Truck
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón

I did, yesterday, and from Casco Viejo! Located right in front of the Lottery building, at Central Avenue and 10th, this place not only is super cute but it...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Several friends have told me that there was this “amazing” fish tacos place in Clayton that we just had to try.  I did, yesterday, and from Casco Viejo!

Located right in front of the Lottery building, at Central Avenue and 10th, this place not only is super cute but it has really good food.  We ordered the green curry fish and the red curry one. Not only we licked the plate, but I almost ordered a second one, and the plate from the table next to me.

Right now they are open only for lunch, but Maurice and Michael (the owners) are considering extending until sunset.  Welcome guys!

item.title: New Business in Casco Viejo: Oshitec
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo For the longest time our friend Hamzah was our version of a knight in shining armor. And I`m serious about it, white horse and everything! He would come to the rescue of my computer and phone system delivering great service. Now, he has opened a business in Casco Viejo! Still...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

For the longest time our friend Hamzah was our version of a knight in shining armor. And I`m serious about it, white horse and everything! He would come to the rescue of my computer and phone system delivering great service. Now, he has opened a business in Casco Viejo!

Still IT related, “OSHITEC” will repair computers, but also will provide other services like internet café, photocopies (you always need one!), international phone calls (always handy for visitors) and sales of CD, USB, and even alarm services.

Where? They are at A Avenue, between 4th and 5th, right in front of the Art Deco building.  Here is their info! Welcome OSHITEC!

This week I`ll be writing about them all, today starting with Finca del Mar (The Sea`s...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

With two oceans at its disposal,Panama is blessed with the ability to get great fish. Entrepreneurs have taken notice, as three new restaurants opened in Casco, two of them focused on fish and seafood. This week I`ll be writing about them all, today starting with Finca del Mar (The Sea`s Farm).

It is located at Calle 2da, by the French Embassy and it is owned and run by a French team.  After spending some days in the Basque coast of France, I`m really looking forward to try their food. The place looks really nice, the open terrace and gardens have a chill ambiance.

They will be opened from 8 a.m. until late at night, so they will be offering breakfast!  Here is their celphone for more info and reservations 6744-6223

item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Gisela Sanchez is a young fashion designer that has her small workshop in Casco Viejo, at Calle 4ta, Santa Familia. She shares a creative space with architects and designers, and through her you can turn any fabric into a beautiful clothing piece made just for you.  She will scout fabrics for you if you don´t have one, and come up with amazing ideas. Everyone I`ve known that have had pieces done by her have been very pleased! so fully recommended.

She was featured in Panama Street Style, and you can contact her at: tallerdegisela@gmail.com  phone: 6566-6119 and follow her on Facebook: El Taller de Gisela.

item.title: Metro Bus: From and To Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Someone approached me the other day about the Metro Bus, if it reached Casco and how to use it. I was confused myself on how to go about it, since they have changed routes and where to get the card, so what I did was to ride it last Sunday...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Someone approached me the other day about the Metro Bus, if it reached Casco and how to use it. I was confused myself on how to go about it, since they have changed routes and where to get the card, so what I did was to ride it last Sunday and here are my notes on it:

CARD: I found myself asking everywhere for one, and no one sold it.  The nearest posts I could verify are: at Plaza 5 de Mayo (the sidewalk next to the old train station) and the stop they call “Mercado de Mariscos” which is actually not at the Fish Market (close, though!) but next to Cochez and the San Felipe Neri Market (you will see a big stop there with an orange fence. The card costs about $2.50 or so, and remember to ask the sales person to charge it with an amount. Each ride is about $0.25, my recommendation is that you plug in $5 and keep the card just in case.

ROUTES: Tricky.  The two closest ones to Casco Viejo are:

Route Ancon – Avenida B:  You can take it at the Santa Ana plaza. This one makes a small loop through Ancon, Santa Ana, Fish Market and back. I didn´t ride the full extent of this, and couldn´t find the map in their website. But I did call the MiBus company and they confirmed.

Route Cinta Costera: The closest “stop” where to take it is at the Cinta Costera, just passing the Fish Market, by the exercise area where they have all the machines.  There are several routes passing through here, most of them go all the way to Paitilla (in case you want to go to Multicentro, Bal Harbour, or the pharmacies and stores there).

Once you take, let`s say, the Cinta Costera out of Casco and want to come back, then most likely you will have to take 2 buses: one to take you to the “Fish Market” stop and one to take you to Santa Ana (a.i. the Ancon- Avenida B route).  Make sure to mark the card “trasbordo” as you are leaving the bus, so that it has a better fee on the next one. If you do have a question, I found the best way is just to ask the drivers. So far, they`ve been very amiable. Not sure they speak English, but they will try to help!

Now, BIG tip, as it is not very obvious: the stop to get the Ancon- Avenida B is actually a few steps away from the Fish Market big stop. It is a small stop (see the small orange sign in photo) next to Republic Parking and the Pantera Rosa. Buses going through this stop are: Ancon- Avenida B and the Chorrillo route. If by mistake you take the Chorrillo route, it is not the end of the world. However, it would take you to Calle 17, which is 3 blocks away from Santa Ana and you need to know where to get down which isn´t easy to recognize. Make sure to approach the driver so he lets you know when to go down. Better keep to Ancon- Avenida B.  And if you feel like walking, you`ll probably get there faster, as this stop is basically at the commercial part of Avenida Central (Central Avenue) and walking is a treat.

item.title: New Store in Casco Viejo! Welcome “Digna y Benito”
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo I went all hyper yesterday at “Digna y Benito”, calle 4ta`s new store in front of Papyro y Yo. The reason? well, it just has beautiful stuff! I used the classic excuse of needing to buy something special for a friend… to buy stuff for me… jejejeje…. The unusual name...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

I went all hyper yesterday at “Digna y Benito”, calle 4ta`s new store in front of Papyro y Yo. The reason? well, it just has beautiful stuff! I used the classic excuse of needing to buy something special for a friend… to buy stuff for me… jejejeje….

The unusual name ties up because of the store`s concept: both “Digno” and “Benita” are common names in Panama`s countryside, specially from the Azuero arch where most of the traditional clothing such as polleras are made. The owners of the store have been working with women from this area, helping them re tool what they know (they do exquisite work, but focused on polleras and traditional clothing) to generate new designs and products.  This small “laboratory” has now lampshades, beautiful shirts and skirts, women`s shoes and even honey from the local farms!

If you are looking for gifts, special souvenirs, or would love to have something made for you, contact them at: info@dignoybenita.com Phone: 391-1199.

item.title: Business Women Meet at Esquina Photo
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Antiguo One of the things I love about Casco is that its community is always opening spaces to meet, mingle and share. That was the occasion when a couple of weeks ago, Esquina Photo along with Ahden Busch organized a get together for “Casco`s business women”. Although I knew many of the girls...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Antiguo

One of the things I love about Casco is that its community is always opening spaces to meet, mingle and share. That was the occasion when a couple of weeks ago, Esquina Photo along with Ahden Busch organized a get together for “Casco`s business women”.  Although I knew many of the girls attending, I did meet new people and loved how different country flags keep adding to Casco Viejo`s neighborhood.  From Panama, Spain, USA, Italy, Jamaica (and I`m probably forgetting a few more), we shared common interests, wine and cheese. Congratulations to Ingrid Moore and Ahden Busch for organizing it! Thank you!!!

item.title: A Dying Trade Kept Alive
item.dc:creator: Patrizia Pinzón
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Yesterday, while doing my home shores, I heard a distinctive flute playing from down the street. I recognized it from my childhood, and I ran down to meet the guy, probably the last one in Panama in his trade. I bet I was the only one in the neighborhood who...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Yesterday, while doing my home shores, I heard a distinctive flute playing from down the street.  I recognized it from my childhood, and I ran down to meet the guy, probably the last one in Panama in his trade. I bet I was the only one in the neighborhood who even knew what the meaning of the flute was.

Mr. Enzo is an Argentinian who has been in Panama for more than 30 years. His trade is a dying one in this era of easy “buy and throw away”. He sharpens. Knives, scissors, machetes, electric knives and even small ones like the tools used for manicure.  His prices range from $1 for a pair of scissors to $3 for a lawn mower. He rides on his bicycle and his only advertising while he roams the street is his flute, which he plays in a very particular way, almost like a Quetzal song.

He will come to your home if you call him: 6023-9378.  For less than $10 I sharpened every knife I had and threw in a machete from a neighbor who does gardening.  His flyer calls himself the “Scissors Doctor”.  It reminded me of a time where people were more frugal, repairing what they had instead of throwing it away.  My knives are now back in shape, cutting as if they were just out of the box.  Fully recommended!

item.title: Casa del Horno Apartments For Sale in Casco Viejo

This building, restored a couple of years ago, opened as a high end hotel at B Avenue, gaining wonderful comments and reviews immediately. The building has a...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

If you`ve been looking for luxury apartments in Casco Viejo, you might be very interested in what Casa del Horno has to offer.

This building, restored a couple of years ago, opened as a high end hotel at B Avenue, gaining wonderful comments and reviews immediately. The building has a beautiful old world feeling, as most of its structure is made of colonial calicanto wall, but blending in a smart way with contemporary interior design.

The hotel group has now opened a second hotel (Casa Nuratti) and are offering the apartments in Casa del Horno for sale. One and two bedrooms, will be served with a special concierge service: laundry on demand, valet parking, 24 hour security, room service.  This is a perfect investment property, zero headaches. The Casa del Horno group will retain the administration of the building, and will remain as owners of L`Osteria and Café del Horno, located at the ground floor.  Here are the prices and sizes for their units:

item.title: MusicArte in Casco Viejo

item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

I was researching the other day different festivals that have established themselves as annual attractions in Casco Viejo.  I knew there were several, but boy we have a full calendar! from the Panama Jazz Festival in January, to the FAE Theater Festival and even the International Film Festival, I think my next posting will be all the cool annual stuff that takes place in Casco so you can plan ahead.

But today I learned about MusicArte, an event that gather musicians from the States and Panama, and not only they do concerts together, but also interesting workshops, mainly focused on composition.  Classic and Contemporary music. Two of their performances will be at Teatro Amador (June 13th and 14th), starting at 8:30 p.m.

Here is the note from La Prensa on it.

item.title: Kids activities in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo The other day I was talking to a friend and he told me how amazed he was at the number of activities his kids were, and all of them between a few blocks from each other. Knowing how parents struggle to get their children to the numerous classes they always inscribe them,...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo

The other day I was talking to a friend and he told me how amazed he was at the number of activities his kids were, and all of them between a few blocks from each other. Knowing how parents struggle to get their children to the numerous classes they always inscribe them, I thought this was worth mentioning. So, here it is!

Music classes: general music appreciation classes at the Danilo Perez Foundation. Here they would learn the different instruments, and tune their ears to great music.  Location: Plaza Herrera

Painting classes: the Olga Sinclair foundation has an amazing way to get your kids inspired. Look for the ultra purple building next to the Danilo Perez Foundation!

Martial Arts (boys and girls!): kids will love their “ninja class” at the Top Level Gym in Calle 4ta. They have crossfit as well for parents and the mini crossfit for children.

Photography classes: run by photographer Tarina Rodriguez and organized through Esquina Photo (Ingrid Moore), I consider photography a fabulous gateway to all art appreciation because of its instant gratification! Tarina is great with kids as well!

And depending on the time of the year, Los Del Patio art center has yoga for kids and a bunch of other stuff. And the best (for the parent) is that commuting time is basically zero: walking from one street to the next, sometimes door to door. Priceless!

item.title: Street games in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo My belly was hurting from so much laughter! Outside my office I heard this really loud noise, children screaming laughing and things falling down, stumbling. I went out and the APROJUSAN kids where playing “congelada” (frozen) and it was to die for. I really can´t remember the last time I...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

My belly was hurting from so much laughter! Outside my office I heard this really loud noise, children screaming laughing and things falling down, stumbling. I went out and the APROJUSAN kids where playing “congelada” (frozen) and it was to die for.  I really can´t remember the last time I played it, but I do remember having tons of fun with it.

Basically, someone is “it” and if he/she touches you, then you are frozen. You can be “defrosted” by a friend that runs and touches you, and there are “havens” (determined in advance) where “it” can´t reach you. The game allows for “chains” which are made by children holding hands, one touching the “haven” and the idea is to reach a “frozen” one to “defrost” him in a safe way. I loved it because it quickly makes kids run like crazy, work in a team, focus on a goal and make the best to “save” their friend.  What could be better!!! In the meantime, it is all chaos… fantastic. At the end, kids where exhausted, sweating, smiling, rushed with endorphins.  As healthy kids should be.

item.title: Casa Nuratti Hotel Inaugurates in Casco Viejo!
item.dc:creator: patrizia

item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Welcome Casa Nuratti! right next to Tantalo, this is a spot for the young soul. The design concept brings hip and recycling together in a fresh, young look and feel. Art hidden in every corner: from photos and crafts from local artists to a a tribute to Blek Le Rat,...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Welcome Casa Nuratti! right next to Tantalo, this is a spot for the young soul. The design concept brings hip and recycling together in a fresh, young look and feel.  Art hidden in every corner: from photos and crafts from local artists to a a tribute to Blek Le Rat, the graffiti French artist who back in the 50`s invented the “stencil graffiti” concept.  You`ll enjoy Nuratti, but specially the roof terrace bar which has a small pool to freshen up. Will it be open to more than guests? I still have to ask!

My favorite part was the thought put up on every room door. Each one is identified with a phrase that opens a question or a riddle that hints you into different parts of Panamanian culture and geography.

Congratulations guys!

item.title: Bienal del Sur Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.category: What to do in Casco Viejo
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo   I kind of dig the mystery and awe of bumping into good/ interesting art in the street. When I travel, I always look for those big or small corners of human expression, that space someone stole from a plaza or a wall and transformed it so that people passing...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

 

I kind of dig the mystery and awe of bumping into good/ interesting art in the street. When I travel, I always look for those big or small corners of human expression, that space someone stole from a plaza or a wall and transformed it so that people passing by had a reaction, a thought, provoked a smiled or a protest. To throw at you a silent question, make you raise or low an eyebrow.  The Bienal in Casco Viejo has been so far a little bit like this. Today I`ll issue my small and humble review from someone who knows absolutely nothing about art.  So far, this is my favorite piece. It is at the Arco Chato, and it made me think about the connectivity we have as humans between each other, and the big floating pieces of adobe suddenly became a presence on its own, one very appropriate in a 300 year old colonial town that was built initially on those very materials. I think there was a story in the Popol Vuh that said that the gods have tried humans out of dirt first and that didn´t work out too well, so later they tried carving us on wood.  Since any of those creatures had much of a feeling, then they tried corn, which was sacred and therefore the legend comes out that we are the result from that final experiment. Seeing the iron/wood/adobe installation somehow reminded me of the materials we are all made of, which I hope was the point of the whole thing. Maybe I`m wrong!   Now, Popol Vuh aside, who is the artist? Silence. There is no sign, no explanation, recognition, big or small or even digital anywhere. Not even at the Biennale website. There is nothing easy to find about the great majority of the guest artists.

Was this mystery in itself part of the artistic happening? I doubt it. But I`m happy I bounced into this piece, I hope you like the photos I took.

item.title: CAPTA Graduates Steal the Show
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Yesterday was the graduation No. 24 of the CAPTA program of Fundación Calicanto. They now have officially graduated over 500 women, with over 73% rate of success on not only getting a job but keeping it a year after. This graduation was very special, because it was one of the...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Yesterday was the graduation No. 24 of the CAPTA program of Fundación Calicanto. They now have officially graduated over 500 women, with over 73% rate of success on not only getting a job but keeping it a year after.

This graduation was very special, because it was one of the very few where I`ve heard some of them state being an entrepreneur as part of their dream (usually they are very focused on getting a job). This on itself is awesome.  For these women who normally come from very difficult/violent backgrounds and in really poor areas, to have that spark it is really something to admire. Between the many gifts they received during their graduation, there was a scholarship for one of the students so she can now finish Elementary School and High School. Yes, you read correctly.

I know that everyone knows how education is a wonderful thing, how empowerment is something good, and etc. etc. etc. But believe me, until you`ve been there, seen it, been part of this program…. You just don´t know how powerful this is.  CAPTA is not just “change” for these women. It is a change for everyone that come across it, and even if for a simple moment, can see the results in real life as opposed to an excel sheet.

Congratulations to every girl in this class, to the teachers, donors and organizers who make this happen against all odds every year. You guys rock!

item.title: Teatro Amador Concerts and Movie Nights

This is “art week” in Panama, with the Bienale del Sur happening all over the place. But specially in Casco Viejo, where you will be able to walk around and bounce into some of the street art pieces (mostly in the plazas) and galleries are hosting their own events.

item.title: Calle 11 Extreme Makeover
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo, Panama For the last few months, members of the Casco Viejo Neighborhood Associatin (AVACA) have been meeting about a growing problem: traffic in the Casco. A handful of business owners, many of them residents, brainstormed and came up with really nice ideas on how to improve it. As a pilot, they...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo, Panama

For the last few months, members of the Casco Viejo Neighborhood Associatin (AVACA) have been meeting about a growing problem: traffic in the Casco. A handful of business owners, many of them residents, brainstormed and came up with really nice ideas on how to improve it.  As a pilot, they decided to start on Calle 11, a street that included several elements of the “problem” (bien cuidados, garbage, illegal parking, broken sidewalks between others).  This is what they did:

With help from all the residents in the street, a plan was designed to park in a nearby lot, so that the cars wouldn´t be on top of the already broken sidewalks. Instead of cars, and to prevent further illegal parking, big plant pots were installed in place. Residents would take care of them, paid by the businesses in the street. Some of them have already started working with a local parking company as “parking guides”, guiding visitors to the parking lots and preventing chaos.  They will be fully identified and in uniform.

Each area was given beautiful garbage cans to use (as they didn´t have them). Also, the traffic flow of the street was changed to improve overall circulation between the two connecting avenues.  Voilà!

Sounds simple, but it was an amazing pilot that was only possible with the full cooperation almost guerrilla style from everyone including the authorities.  The SPI and Tránsito were unbelievably helpful, and so were the people in the street. Here are photos of before and after, but even if you can´t see the mess or the importance of the difference, people living there do know.  Just to give you a hint: now the street is usable. The first thing they did when it was clean was to …. actually start using it! they took out a barbeque on the weekend, children could play without garbage up to their noses. Now the lady who sells fried patacones has a really nice spot to put tables and chairs, so her local business can grow, fueled by clients who now will be attracted (and able) to walk up this street in search for more restaurants.

What are the next steps? they are working in setting up a training program for the local youth in the street who are looking to be able to apply for better jobs.  Also, the association is looking forward to extend the programs to other areas where the authorities have detected illegal parking which is creating problems for everyone.  The best thing is that these plant pots can now be an urban garden project, helping residents from each street grow their own herbs and vegetables.

There where so many helping hands in this project, it really took a village!

Here the main participants, keep in mind that each street will have a new group involved:

Businesses:

Rana Dorada, Mojitos, Onplog, Las Clementinas, Conservatorio S.A., Casco Parking, Diablo Rosso, Papiro y Yo, Amicale, Los Cuatro Tulipanes, Pensión Panamericana

Hands on!

Juan Londoño, Ricky Sandoval, Johann Wolfshoon, Kc Hardin, Zaira Lombardo, Eric Theise, Matt Landau, Ricardo Garcés, Cherie Flagg, Itav Avital, Scott y su team de construcción, Franz (mover los potes), Rogelio Jaramillo, Marteen, Jennifer Hotsko and Fábrega

Government authorities:

SPI: Sub Comisionado Cenèn Castillo & team

Tránsito: Lic. Carlos Ayuso

item.title: Historic Real Estate: Cartagena
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Interesting article about Cartagena, Colombia`s colonial town. Because it started its revitalization before Panama`s historic district of Casco Antiguo, it is probably one of the best cases to show the path of evolution of historic real estate in the region. For those of you who have followed prices and trends...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Interesting article about Cartagena, Colombia`s colonial town. Because it started its revitalization before Panama`s historic district of Casco Antiguo, it is probably one of the best cases to show the path of evolution of historic real estate in the region.  For those of you who have followed prices and trends through Arco`s blog and listings in Casco Viejo, I`m sure you will find this reading extremely interesting.  One of the easiest things to compare is always the price range per restored mt2. Qualities being similar, Panama`s Casco Viejo is still between $2500 to $3000 (in the case of commercial spaces and some really special homes) per mt2, while in Cartagena for a similar level of restored home is difficult to find a product below $5000 per mt2. A lot of this value rocketed when hotels like the famous Santa Clara “hit town” and opened doors in Cartagena. Similarly, Panama is about to experience the same dynamics with all the hotels opening doors at the ends of 2013, specially the American Trade Hotel.

Five hundred years of colour

Colombia property Nick Foster on the up-and-coming Old Town mansions of Cartagena

item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

The second edition of the International Film Festival Panama starts tomorrow, with a red carpet gala at the National Theater in Casco Viejo.  The movie chosen for the special opening is Blancanieves (from Spain – 90`s) which according to the summary is a romantic story based in the Spain of the 20`s, where a young girl has to escape her evil stepmother to find her fame and glory as a “matadora”.  Language in Spanish, subtitles in English!

See the schedule of every film below. Here is the “key” to understand where they will be shown:

TN National Theater Casco Viejo

AV  Anita Villalaz Theater Casco Viejo

AL Outdoor screening Casco Viejo – Parque V Centenario

CM = cinépolis movies (Panama City)

item.title: New! Guayabera opens a store in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo The Guayabera is a classic image of tropical elegance. Usually associated with Cuba, many don´t know it has always been very popular in Panama because it has a flair that reminds us of our traditional “camisilla”. I remember being always envious of those fresh shirts men got to wear, until recently, when...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo

The Guayabera is a classic image of tropical elegance. Usually associated with Cuba, many don´t know it has always been very popular in Panama because it has a flair that reminds us of our traditional “camisilla”.  I remember being always envious of those fresh shirts men got to wear, until recently, when “Panabrisa” started making dresses for women on the same style. Loved them!

So you can imagine my enthusiasm when “Guayaberas”, the store that carries Panabrisa (a brand with more than 50 years designing and selling guayaberas) showed an interest in Casco Viejo. After a lot of back and forth, specially putting up with the repairs of the roads in the area, finally they took a big step yesterday and opened their doors to the public.  I rushed in and grabbed my ticket to be the first customer!

They have really nice stuff, from the classic male models to dresses (and if you ask they also have baby guayaberas!).  Also they have pillow cases, bags and other products like designed hats and jewerly by Annie Chajin.

Go check them out! where? corner of 4th and A Avenue, in front of Arco! Miriam Pons will be there to help you choose or take special requests (miriam@guayabera.net )

Visit them on Facebook

And see their product here:

And photos!

What I like about this small project is that it took literally nothing, it was fun to do and gave me instant gratification. My...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo

A while ago I started to make my own Christmas Tree using recycled stuff. This obsession has now spread to other holidays, and today I`m trying with Easter.  What I like about this small project is that it took literally nothing, it was fun to do and gave me instant gratification. My kind of thing!

These rocks I picked up at Casco`s beach in Calle 4ta, painted them last night and made the nest with some palms I found around. Voila! Looking forward to the next holiday…

Modern decor inside, they seem to be leaning towards tapas. My best picks so far have been the “Mero” and the “Robalo” (Snook).  They also have a beautiful chocolat fondant!

item.title: Shopping for Antiques in Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo One of the founders of Arco Properties had a passion for antique furniture. I learned a lot from him, developing an eye for interesting stuff hidden in the houses in the barrio. I always thought there would be a good niche for an “antique stuff” district in Panama, and that...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

One of the founders of Arco Properties had a passion for antique furniture. I learned a lot from him, developing an eye for interesting stuff hidden in the houses in the barrio. I always thought there would be a good niche for an “antique stuff” district in Panama, and that it should logically be in Casco Viejo. Well, I think I got my wish! little by little…

That place is Plaza Arango. A few steps away from Las Clementinas, you will find now three antique vendors, one beside the other. The oldest one in the street basically has no name, you just bounce into it. He has a good collection of silver spoons, forks and then the classic bottles, water pitches, etc. Old records too!

Next to it, and the newest in the block is a “garage sale” of antiques. Big and small furniture, including the classic sewing machines that make for beautiful desks and tables. They even have a barber chair!

To its left you can find Canal Zone. Probably the best window and wider collection. They have plenty of things from the old Canal Zone times, so you can mix and match.

Now you can stroll and shop for antiques in Casco, fantastic! as it would be anywhere in the world, remember always to bargain!

Congratulations to Scotiabank for supporting CAPTA, it really makes a difference!

Nice pizza, breath taking desserts and Manuela`s personal sweet charm has made it an icon in Casco Viejo. Always attentive and eager to help or participate, she has a...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Five years ago, Manuela Rossetti opened Caffé per Due (Coffee for two) near the corner of A Avenue and First street.  Nice pizza, breath taking desserts and Manuela`s personal sweet charm has made it an icon in Casco Viejo. Always attentive and eager to help or participate, she has a special place in everyone`s hearts in Casco.

Needless to say, the party was packed! not only in people, but also in hugs, congratulations and true neighborly love.

Felicidades Manuela!!!!  Happy Bday Caffé per Due!!

item.title: Teatro Amador is Back!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Santa Ana Teatro Amador is a beautiful theater located in Santa Ana, just after the traffic light. It always caught my imagination because of my father`s stories about his childhood. He used to go there to watch movies (at some point it was both theater and movie theater), specially Flash Gordon. For...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Santa Ana

Teatro Amador is a beautiful theater located in Santa Ana, just after the traffic light. It always caught my imagination because of my father`s stories about his childhood. He used to go there to watch movies (at some point it was both theater and movie theater), specially Flash Gordon. For $0.15 a day, you could stay there for hours, because first would be the news, then a raffle or similar and finally the movie.

Finally, the theater has been restored and it is breaking several marks in one: it is the first privately restored theater and the first renovated building in Santa Ana, marking a new era for the area.

This Friday, the soft opening will be dedicated to Casco Viejo`s neighbors, specially members of the AVACA group. We are glad to see new and interesting concepts entering the area, and very specially history being brought back!

Needless to say…. I`m taking dad to the opening! can´t wait!!!

item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

March is always the backdrop for Panama`s two week long spring. With the first rains, all the trees bloom. Last week, as coordinated by an invisible orchestra director, all the “robles” tuned in together playing the exact note of pink. People sat around and under the trees, but I took a photo of this cute cat sleeping in the middle of the flower carpet.  It looked so comfortable!!!

item.title: Carnivals are almost here!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo This weekend, the whole country will go upside down. Almost everyone in Panama City will travel to the country side, in a massive exodus to celebrate until Wednesday all they can celebrate. Many will be with their families, and towns like Las Tablas, Penonomé and just anything with beaches will be the...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo

This weekend, the whole country will go upside down. Almost everyone in Panama City will travel to the country side, in a massive exodus to celebrate until Wednesday all they can celebrate. Many will be with their families, and towns like Las Tablas, Penonomé and just anything with beaches will be the primary destinations.

This year we`ll stay behind, in Casco Viejo, and enjoy the almost unbelievable transformation of an entire capital gone ghost town! What we`ll do in Casco? probably join the kids who will run after anyone they see with a bucket of water and throw it on top just to run and hide (or not even hide but laugh their heads off). The second best attraction is to see the improvised band that always ends up in Calle 4ta and Calle 5ta playing with anything they can find (bottles, boxes, frankly, anything)!.  They can actually sing! even after beer…

item.title: Soccer, Super Bowl and Yoga in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia

On Sunday everyone enjoyed the Super Bowl at El Sitio del Casco (what a game!) and today the whole country will tune into the soccer game Panama vs Costa Rica. Here it will be an event at the newly...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo

Yes, that`s right… This month in Casco has had a bit of everything.

On Sunday everyone enjoyed the Super Bowl at El Sitio del Casco (what a game!) and today the whole country will tune into the soccer game Panama vs Costa Rica.  Here it will be an event at the newly opened Barlovento, Casco`s new spot at the corner of Central Avenue and 10th. From there, it will be straight up partying from Saturday until Wednesday (carnivals) and finally on February 16th your soul will find peace at Los Del Patio with a nice, relaxing event including foot massage, yoga and desserts! sign me in!!!

item.title: Starting 2013 with New Businesses, New Offers and Anniversaries!

We just missed on an audio visual festival, but we look forward to the Film Festival coming to Casco this April. I`ll post more on that later. This Sunday, our friend...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama

After being away for a while on vacation, we just came back to a good number of new stuff going on!

We just missed on an audio visual festival, but we look forward to the Film Festival coming to Casco this April. I`ll post more on that later. This Sunday, our friend Matt Landau will proudly represent Casco on the second edition of IronMan Panama.  Big OMG on that one! And also, a number of little places have been opening their doors to our delight, or counting their first anniversary birthday candle. Casco keeps moving forward! here is the info on some of the latest offers, businesses and initiatives!

Casa Sucre Coffee House: corner of Calle 8 and B Avenue, diagonal to Tantalo, this is an owner run café by Alice and Richard Sherman. They put a homey touch to everything they do: above is Casa Sucre Bed and Breakfast and below is now their coffee house.

Also, La Petite Bretagne is having their first anniversary! Here is the info on their offers for their special February 7th:

And also great stuff coming from Las Clementinas! Special Lunch Menu at $9.50.  If you call them, they can send the “carrito” (golf cart) to pick you up wherever you are in Casco: 228-7613

item.title: Casco Viejo VIP Card: Enjoy Casco Viejo in Style!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo Imagine a card that would give you great offers at your favorite places in Casco Viejo. Really cool stuff like discounts and special access so you can enjoy with your friends and family. Such card exists!!! Yes! welcome to the “Casqueño Card” ! Hundreds of dollars in savings for only $50. All...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo

Imagine a card that would give you great offers at your favorite places in Casco Viejo. Really cool stuff like discounts and special access so you can enjoy with your friends and family. Such card exists!!!

Yes! welcome to the “Casqueño Card” !

Hundreds of dollars in savings for only $50.  All profits will go to AVACA, Casco Viejo`s Neighborhood and Friend`s Association (see more about AVACA here). Are you already an AVACA member? email  and get a special offer! director@avaca.org.pa

How does it work?

  • Buy the card at:  Las Clementinas,  Hotel Tantalo and Relic
  • Activate the card at El Casqueño  (Soon will have a Paypal Acct)
  • Present it at the businesses listed below!

These offers will be active ALL YEAR ROUND.  The website El Casqueño will be featuring temporary offers as well, so keep tuned!

Super Gourmet

Diablicos

Veggie Moon

Panamericana

Diablo Rosso

Los Cuatro Tulipanes

Canal House

Casco Station

($50-30% + ITBMS).
