It was amazing, their rooftop terrace has almost a 360 degree view of Casco and Panama City. The city itself becomes your private firework show, from Paitilla to the Ghery Museum in Amador. This year,...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

 

Last year, we had the pleasure of being at Las Clementinas for New Years. It was amazing, their rooftop terrace has almost a 360 degree view of Casco and Panama City. The city itself becomes your private firework show, from Paitilla to the Ghery Museum in Amador.

This year, Las Clementinas will open again its panoramic roof terrace.  Dinner will include a delicious menu featuring lobster and unlimited mimosas. It is the perfect spot if you don´t like crowds and prefer a more elegant, intimate ambiance.

By the way, the brunch the next day promises to be really yummy… see the menu at the photos attached.

Call now!

Ph. 228-7613/ 7617

item.title: Neighborhood Christmas Party builds a future for children in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo   On Tuesday, “La Vecindad” was packed with children. Almost 200 kids running around, some jumping literally up and down. The party, which started a couple of years ago, was organized by Idalibeth, a local neighbor and supported by AVACA members. What`s special about this party is that it joins...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

 

On Tuesday, “La Vecindad” was packed with children. Almost 200 kids running around, some jumping literally up and down. The party, which started a couple of years ago, was organized by Idalibeth, a local neighbor and supported by AVACA members.

What`s special about this party is that it joins kids from all parts of Casco Viejo, especially those who are sons and daughters of rival gangs deep into the poorest parts of Santa Ana.  Idalibeth herself was part of one of those gangs, until a social program showed her a better way. After that she became an entrepreneur with her mother, and ever since she took control of her own life, she has taken this party to help these kids make friends among them, blurring the imaginary frontiers that adults might still have in their heads. Many of those kids today are part of social programs as well: Enlaces (Calicanto), Aprojusan, Fundación San Felipe, Fundación Danilo Pérez, Fundación Olga Sinclair and even the Scouts.  Here is where the future is being made using all the right ingredients.

Congratulations Ida!

item.title: Spaying event a success in Casco Viejo!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo Dra. Patricia Chan is an unstoppable force. When you meet her, you know immediately you are in front of a non nonsense person with a deep commitment to the cause. And what a great cause: to clear the streets from unspayed animals, making for a healthier city and happier pets...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

Dra. Patricia Chan is an unstoppable force. When you meet her, you know immediately you are in front of a non nonsense person with a deep commitment to the cause. And what a great cause: to clear the streets from unspayed animals, making for a healthier city and happier pets (and owners!).

This past Sunday, Spay Panama along with Angeles de los Animales and members from AVACA (Casco Antiguo`s Neighborhood Association) spayed about 60 animals (mainly dogs and cats). The event was amazing, and it benefited neighbors that otherwise wouldn´t have had the means to operate their pets.

The event was held at the Santa Familia Community Center, at the space facilitated by Top Level Gym Congratulations to everyone involved in this wonderful event!

If you would like to donate to Spay Panama, please contact them HERE.

item.content:encoded:

I`ve been having trouble to upload photos, but there has been so much happening! from the beautiful Carols by the Candlelight concert to small events that range from fashion (Miss Moss at the Casa de la Municipalidad) to small carols at Plaza Catedral by local NGO`s.

Today, a big neighborhood party will be happening at Calle 4ta, with more than 200 children from Casco Viejo. I hope I have more luck tomorrow uploading photos! this is a wonderful and pretty fun event, where children from every area of the historic city come together and share.

item.title: Caribbean Style at Colonial Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Real Estate and History Panama Panamanians will easily tell you that Panama`s population is a “crisol de razas”, an expression that means the country is a melting pot. Because of our geographic location, Panama became a natural trading hub. It is been said that it was here were tribes from...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo
Real Estate and History Panama

Panamanians will easily tell you that Panama`s population is a “crisol de razas”, an expression that means the country is a melting pot. Because of our geographic location, Panama became a natural trading hub. It is been said that it was here were tribes from both north and south met to trade. It certainly served its purpose during colonial times, and even today Panama is considered the “hub of the Americas”. As you may guess, this diversity showed in Panama`s culture and DNA, but there are very few places in Panama City where you can witness the architectural legacy of this melting pot better than in Casco Viejo.

Here is a clear example of this diversity: Casa de Abuela.

Even though Casco Viejo was “born” as a Spanish colonial city, the city itself was built and re built (it burnt three times almost to the ground) according to the influx of people that would come in waves to, for example, trade during the Gold Rush, build the French Canal, later with the American Canal. So you find here not only colonial style architecture, but beautiful examples of everything else both in an almost “pure” form or fusion.

One of the least well known styles in Casco Viejo is the Caribbean Style. Casa de Abuela is a beautiful and original example of Caribbean Style. It has a unique shape, a wide balcony with water views. The house took advantage of the wind corridor that hits the corner where its located by introducing throughout the walls “respiraderos” (breathers) in addition to windows. The upper level is double height and an attic at the roof serves as extra room but also as a flow for hot air to escape.

Records show the block existing since 1675, however, because Casco Viejo was caught in several important fires, records start mentioning this house around 1875.

Finding out a bit about 1875, and just to compare with what the World was doing back then, I find out that it was the year where George Bizet died and Camille Saint Saens premiered “Danse Macabre”, one of my favorite classical pieces. Panama was still part of Colombia.

An interesting info, thinking about the style of the house and its prominent location nearby the Presidential compound and one of Casco Viejo`s main plazas, might be that in Panama, slavery was officially abolished in 1850`s. The style and important location might be a witness of the actual roll that the black community, specially Afroantillians played in Panamanian society by then. Comparing, for example, to the United States at that time, I find out that still in 1875 they were forming Anti Slavery Societies (New York), which was very much an issue that continued to be so for much longer in that country… but somehow not in Panama. As a matter of fact, by 1893 one of Panama`s most important poets was born: Gaspar Octavio Hernández, later referred as the “Black Swan” because of his origins and elegant writing style. He used to work as a journalist at La Estrella de Panamá, one of Panama`s most important newspapers of the day.

Looking at “Casa de Abuela”, looking at the year it was built, the place where it is, its tropical elegance and details, I get the sense there is a hidden and beautiful history (if not lesson) behind it waiting to be discovered. Only in Casco Viejo!

Looking to restore a similar project? contact us now!
clara@arcoproperties.com
Patrizia@arcoproperties.com

item.title: Glass Bottle Christmas Tree
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo Two years ago, I started shifting from the traditional Christmas tree to ones made with recycled materials. The first year I made one with newspapers and miscellaneous stuff I found at the beach. The second year, the theme was plastic bottles, also found at the beach. I used about 80...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

Two years ago, I started shifting from the traditional Christmas tree to ones made with recycled materials. The first year I made one with newspapers and miscellaneous stuff I found at the beach.  The second year, the theme was plastic bottles, also found at the beach. I used about 80 bottles or so on that one. Check out both photos HERE. This year, I thought it would be cool to do one with glass bottles, as glass looks always so elegant.

Luckily for me, I live in front of Di Vino, a wine bar in Casco Viejo who handles all of their glass to Casco`s recycling center (on the other side of the street).  So all I had to do was to go there with a big bag and seat for 30 minutes and sort glass bottles out.  I`ve always been attracted to bottles, I have some old bottles from the Canal days and others that have weird or beautiful shapes. For my tree, I went with Perrier and Evian Pure bottles, because I liked their small and round shape.  I didn´t want the tree to be huge because of fear of my dog knocking it out.

So here it is! a work in progress… but looking quite good!

item.title: Casco Viejo Community Celebrates Thanksgiving
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Casco Viejo`s Friends and Neighbors Association (AVACA) gathered last night at Casa del Horno to celebrate Thanksgiving. At least four or five languages were being spoken in the party: Spanish, English, Italian, French and German. And at least two dialects: Spanglish and Itañol. A beautifully eclectic community celebrated and shared...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Casco Viejo`s Friends and Neighbors Association (AVACA) gathered last night at Casa del Horno to celebrate Thanksgiving. At least four or five languages were being spoken in the party: Spanish, English, Italian, French and German.  And at least two dialects: Spanglish and Itañol.   A beautifully eclectic community celebrated and shared food among friends, children running everywhere.

“Did you notice children here speak four different languages?” said Clara, my associate and lifeforce behind the party.  I looked around and saw them playing together and thought, well, somehow they are understanding each other pretty well!

The food was delicious and better yet among friends, Thanksgiving is a wonderful moment were new neighbors get to know old ones and in tune with what`s going on.

Congratulations to the organizers and thanks to Casa del Horno for lending AVACA its beautiful restaurant space!

item.title: Alliance Francaise in Casco Antiguo presents Eco Art
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.category: What to do in Casco Viejo
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo   The Alliance Francaise is presenting for free at the French Embassy in Plaza Francia (Las Bovedas) the show “Dialogue coco- bamboo, Biodiversity, Humanity and Art” by artist Valérie Leblet. The show, which took a year to put together, will be part of a broader event featuring workshops and talks...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

 

The Alliance Francaise is presenting for free at the French Embassy in Plaza Francia (Las Bovedas) the show “Dialogue coco- bamboo, Biodiversity, Humanity and Art” by artist Valérie Leblet.  The show, which took a year to put together, will be part of a broader event featuring workshops and talks about nature and all things green.

The show is for free and the workshops are quite interesting:

Nov. 21st: Nature`s School.  6:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m.

Nov. 22nd: Bamboo Workshop for adults . 6:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m.

(Note that on the 22nd there is also a nice concert at the National Theatre by the German Chamber Orchestra: Signum Quartet, it is at 8 p.m. )

Nov. 23rd: Talk from “Bicicool” , a movement that is trying to incentive the use of bicycles in the city.  6:30 p.m to 7: 30 p.m.

Nov. 24th: Healthy Kitchen, workshop and tasting! Cost: $15.

If you are interested in participating, call 223-7376.  The art show will be open from Mondays to Thursdays, starting at 9 a.m. until 8 p.m.  On Saturdays until 5:30 p.m.

Here is the full note from La Prensa

item.title: Beautiful Garbage Tanks Flood Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo Yesterday, under the rain, a group of residents in Casco Antiguo went out “guerrilla style” and distributed 18 beautiful garbage tanks decorated by Panamanian artists. Like “positive art bombs”, the guerrilla group moved swiftly through A Avenue, in an almost military operation to inject the historic city with fun urban...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

Yesterday, under the rain, a group of residents in Casco Antiguo went out “guerrilla style” and distributed 18 beautiful garbage tanks decorated by Panamanian artists.  Like “positive art bombs”, the guerrilla group moved swiftly through A Avenue, in an almost military operation to inject the historic city with fun urban creativity.

This project belongs to AVACA, Casco Antiguo`s Neighborhood and Friend`s Association, an organization that aims to see Casco Viejo become one of the greatest historic districts of the World.  From beach cleanings, to planting palms, Neighborhood Watch Program and even serve as a watchman for law enforcement, AVACA is usually involved in most of the community activities in Casco Antiguo.

The goal with this “Art -Tank” project is to help educate the public into disposing the garbage correctly, while providing with much needed tanks and beautifying the streets by injecting some great urban art.  Yesterday, already under the rain, locals were pointing out the cans and saying “look! look! wao!”. The cans were so pretty they thought twice about throwing garbage inside!

AVACA aims to collect enough funding to create 200 cans and be able to cover neighborhoods like Santa Ana.  So far,  in less than two months they`ve reached 40 cans and enthusiasm has grown.

Thumbs up to all the people who have helped and continue to help in this beautiful project!

item.title: Building in Casco Viejo Wins Restoration Award
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo   Wednesday night we went to the award dinner hosted by Panama`s Architects and Engineers Association and Panama`s Architecture School. Every year, these two organizations study a number of buildings from Panamanian designers and award in different categories. This year, Casco Viejo got its award through Benedetti Hermanos, an Art...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo, Casco Antiguo

 

Wednesday night we went to the award dinner hosted by Panama`s Architects and Engineers Association and Panama`s Architecture School.  Every year, these two organizations study a number of buildings from Panamanian designers and award in different categories.

This year, Casco Viejo got its award through Benedetti Hermanos, an Art Deco building restored by Conservatorio S.A. The architects in charge of the project were Hildegard Vásquez and Daniel Young from the firm Hache Uve.

Congratulations again to the team!

Interested in another development by the same team? Ask us about CASA VIDAL

Write us at: Clara@arcoproperties.com   or Patrizia@arcoproperties.com

item.title: Holiday Parties in Casco Viejo Strenghten Community Programs
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.category: What to do in Casco Viejo
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo   Holidays are basically here, Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year… tons of things going on, and Casco Viejo isn´t the exception. However, many of the events held during this season in Casco Viejo are aimed to help the community, by either fundraising for a local ngo o directly doing something with...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama, Casco Antiguo

 

Holidays are basically here, Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year… tons of things going on, and Casco Viejo isn´t the exception. However, many of the events held during this season in Casco Viejo are aimed to help the community, by either fundraising for a local ngo o directly doing something with the neighbors.

The first event of the season is really Thanksgiving, at the ends of November. This party is organized by members of AVACA, Casco Viejo`s Neighbors and Friends Association. It is a place to meet other neighbors and share wonderful food and wine. Every year, the party change places, normally featuring a new business, so that everyone gets to know it and welcome it.

For those of you who are living in Casco Viejo but are not yet part of AVACA, this would be a great opportunity to meet new people and learn about their programs. Joining is easy and their projects are fun. If you would like to go, please email us at: clara@arcoproperties.com  and save the date: November 24th.

For Christmas, there are all sorts of small and big initiatives.  But this year, the CanadaPLUS club is starting a “Candlelight Carol” that promises to grow year after year. All proceeds will go to Fundación Calicanto, a local ngo that works with women and children from the area.

The event will be absolutely delightful: an open air concert at Plaza Francia (Las Bovedas) with music by different choruses and the participation of the musicians from the Danilo Perez Foundation.  The event is on December 3rd, and will start at Plaza Catedral, where a procession of children carrying candles will walk all the way to Las Bovedas. And there, around 7 p.m. the concert will start.

For this event, there will be candles for sale, and you can reserve a good spot at the plaza (with a chair). Remember, all the proceeds go to Calicanto, so if you are thinking on coming, bring your family and friends!  For more information on this event, call David at 6689-6890 or email at clubcanadaplus@gmail.com

item.title: Panama History: Arco Properties Recommends
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama November is one of those “love `em or hate `em” months in Panama, mainly because we managed (don´t know how, really) to fit all of our patriot holidays in the same month, and as a result nobody really works, nothing moves. So, if you are planning to come to Panama for business...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama

November is one of those “love `em or hate `em” months in Panama, mainly because we managed (don´t know how, really) to fit all of our patriot holidays in the same month, and as a result nobody really works, nothing moves. So, if you are planning to come to Panama for business either 2, 3, 4, 5, 10 or 28th of November, just don´t bother.  Also, please check if any of those fall close to the weekend, for if it does, don´t bother either. We call that “bridging”. I mean, what`s the point of showing up for work on a Friday if Thursday is a holiday and Monday too, right?

But, if you are coming to experience holidays in Panama, this is a great month.  You`ll see the city all dressed up, flags everywhere. Panama City pretty much empties for the first week and a half, everyone goes to the beach and mountains.  If you stay one day at Panama City you`ll see those classic parades where schools march forever, kids with proud faces playing at their best.  Being part of a music band here at school is a big thing, they practice all year round for those marches. But pretty much any town you`ll go they`ll have their own version. Small towns are wonderful, their “main plazas” are usually at the heart of the parade. You`ll see everyone in town, if you want to mingle with locals, this is when you do it.  Take an umbrella, it might rain!

When in town (or before coming to Panama), and even if you are already a seasoned “Panama ” visitor, don´t miss the opportunity of reading “The Path Between the Seas”. It is a fascinating book, one of the best history books we`ve read about this country (and frankly, ever).   David McCullough is an amazing story teller, weaving facts with such natural disposition, you won´t be able to put the book aside. How a small country ended up in the middle of the World`s politics of its time, how it became independent without dropping one single drop of blood. Remarkable.

You`ll enjoy the country from a different perspective, and if you stay in our 300 year old colonial city called Casco Viejo, you`ll be literally walking the same streets that witnessed so many events.

Happy Patriot Holidays!

item.title: Halloween and Panama`s ghosts traditions
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama Trick or Treat! three beautiful kids knocked our door for some candy. Luckily I had some, so I wouldn`t be “attacked” by the fierce pirate or eaten by the Chinese-Ghost- Princess and her ballerina companion. Maybe they would have turned me into a toad or something. And after several months of not...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama

Trick or Treat! three beautiful kids knocked our door for some candy. Luckily I had some, so I wouldn`t be “attacked” by the fierce pirate or eaten by the Chinese-Ghost- Princess and her ballerina companion.  Maybe they would have turned me into a toad or something. And after several months of not missing my gym I would NOT want that!!!

Although Halloween is not a Panamanian tradition, we surely have plenty of ghost stories! Although it`s kind of unfair, Halloween`s origins seemed not to have had anything to do with it other than honoring ancestors and trying to scare away any bad spirits that would come with the change of seasons (Autumn to scary, cold, deadly, Winter).

Our ghost stories are less “nature” oriented, one of the most famous ones being the “Tulivieja” which is supposed to be a woman that lost her baby at a river and ever since she roams the forests and homes in search for it. She is supposed to be “heard” crying at night (close to midnight, of course) and is said to take the infants at their sleep. One of the recommended measures to avoid the Tulivieja (or any witch) from taking you or whomever is to wear your clothes upside down.

So now you know! Here are the lovely ghosts that visited us yesterday. Happy Halloween to everyone!!!

 

For more on La Tulivieja:

item.title: Falling in love with Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo During the 80`s and 90`s Casco Viejo fell to its lower point. Completely abandoned, it created a reputation as a dangerous place, not to be visited by anyone. In 1998, when it got designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO the revitalization process started, and today, it hosts some of the finest...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo

During the 80`s and 90`s Casco Viejo fell to its lower point. Completely abandoned, it created a reputation as a dangerous place, not to be visited by anyone.  In 1998, when it got designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO the revitalization process started, and today, it hosts some of the finest homes, restaurants, bars and cultural events in the city.

The younger generations have started to “return” and inject their energy through art galleries and more. The most recent “injection” of love has been launched in the form of a website: Yo Amo Casco (I Love Casco), a site that promises to be a great place to find the latest on cultural events, nightlife and just life in Casco Viejo.

Check it out at: I LOVE CASCO

item.title: International Film Festival Panama Launched at Clementinas
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo Last night, the roof terrace at Las Clementinas in Casco Viejo was the place to be. A beautiful night, Casco Viejo neighbors and business owners were able to learn more about the upcoming International Film Festival that will be held in Panama next April 2012. One of the most important announcements was...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo

Last night, the roof terrace at Las Clementinas in Casco Viejo was the place to be.  A beautiful night, Casco Viejo neighbors and business owners were able to learn more about the upcoming International Film Festival that will be held in Panama next April 2012.   One of the most important announcements was that Panama`s government has officially given $1M to fund this important event, and now the opportunity is open for private businesses to participate.

The IFF Panama is being organized by Henk Van Der Kolk, founder of the Toronto International Film Festival who has now retired to Panama. The team includes Panamanian film maker and producer Pituka Heilbron.  If you are interested in participating in their sponsorship program, don´t hesitate to contact them at : henk@iffpanama.com

item.title: Panama`s Architecture Restoration Award goes to Hache Uve
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Viejo Hache Uve, one of the main restoration firms in Casco Viejo just got awarded on the “Restoration” category by Panama`s Architects and Engineers Association (SPIA). The “Premio Magno” was given for their work restoring Benedetti Hermanos, a Casco Viejo building from the 1920`s reflecting the Art Deco wave that made it into...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Viejo

Hache Uve, one of the main restoration firms in Casco Viejo just got awarded on the “Restoration” category by Panama`s Architects and Engineers Association (SPIA).

The “Premio Magno” was given for their work restoring Benedetti Hermanos, a Casco Viejo building from the 1920`s reflecting the Art Deco wave that made it into the colonial city and became part of its unique architectural eclecticism.  Many details from the original building were kept, sometimes even on its raw form to allow the building itself tell its story:  original stairs, glass elevator overlooking original bricks, the height of the apartments, and of course, the elegant facade which features a beautiful glass and wood commercial window which was rescued from historic photographs.

Here are some historic photos of the building and how it looks today. The developer, Conservatorio S.A. , was recently awarded with the Global Vision Award (read more here) and together with Hache Uve is now restoring what will be a fifty room hotel (American Trade Hotel) with an events space right in front.

Congratulations! Keep up the good work!

Las Clementinas has the most fun transportation system of Casco Viejo: we call it “El Carrito”.  A very comfortable 6 seat golf car, the “carrito” takes Clementina`s guests and restaurant clients wherever they like within the Casco and is really fantastic.

Got people visiting from out of town? have a nice meal at the restaurant and complete the experience with a quick Casco Viejo tour with El Carrito. Very, very handy for those Friday nights when you are out with your friends and decided to wear sexy stilettos!  Carlos, the driver, speaks English and Spanish.

item.title: Business Opportunities in Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Real Estate For Rent, Casco Viejo, Panama Casco Viejo is buzzing with activity. Construction everywhere, hotels getting ready to open. Opportunities for small and larger businesses have started to open, from medium size commercial spaces to technically unrestored buildings that can be put together in “no time”. Here are the best real estate and business...
item.content:encoded:
Real Estate For Rent, Casco Viejo, Panama

Casco Viejo is buzzing with activity. Construction everywhere, hotels getting ready to open. Opportunities for small and larger businesses have started to open, from medium size commercial spaces to technically unrestored buildings that can be put together in “no time”.

Here are the best real estate and business opportunities in Casco Viejo right now!

Developer Hot Deal:

Water View Building: full concrete structure, any developer or contractor with some experience that takes a look into this building will start jumping on one foot out of joy. No demolition necessary (only for aesthetics), basically is a “plumbing, electricity, roof & paint” job in order to get it ready to start producing some income. Ideas for the building have included a young, budget 15 room hotel to 12 one bedroom rental apartments. Maybe an office building? the place can be anything, with very little investment. The best is that it has the ability to hit the middle market, which very few can. Nothing like a niche market to make a profit!

Restaurant Real Estate For Rent:

If you are not in a hurry and your concept needs more than 200 mt2, Casa Baluarte might be the right space for you. Currently under construction, the project is divided into two spaces: corner restaurant and a roof terrace café. Both spaces will be delivered without finishes, so each tenant can create the necessary ambiance.

You would like to open sooner? Casa Feraud might be your space. It is a raw commercial space, but in a very visible corner. Renovation of the space is needed, so owners are willing to be flexible. Steps away from other restaurants and future hotels already under construction!

Retail Space for Rent: Office, Bank, Wine Store n More Space:

Benedetti Hermanos is by far the biggest and most flexible space of them all. With over 400 mt2 in two wide floors, its commanding fasade at the widest part of Central Avenue is an elegant statement for any business. Glass from floor to ceiling and an “old Madison Avenue” feel, this is an open canvas!

item.title: Hand Made Colonial Tiles in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Viejo A signature feature of colonial apartments in Casco Viejo is the use of hand made tiles. Colorful designs that are set up as carpets, one different for each room. Sometimes they cover the entire area, sometimes just in the middle. You may not realize those tiles on the floor are not massed...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Viejo

A signature feature of colonial apartments in Casco Viejo is the use of hand made tiles.  Colorful designs that are set up as carpets, one different for each room. Sometimes they cover the entire area, sometimes just in the middle.  You may not realize those tiles on the floor are not massed produced. They are hand made! yes…. “Old World” style, one by one… with love!

Check out this interesting video that will show you how each piece is created!

Curious to see how the finished product looks like? This is La Merced, a colonial building in Casco Viejo with two units for sale!

item.title: Breakfast Specials at Baron Rojo, Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama Casco Antiguo “El Barón Rojo” (The Red Baron) is a small café at Calle 4ta and Avenida A, next to Arco Properties. Brand new spot, so you won`t see the sign out yet! but you`ll see the chairs outside. Their specialty: wonderful breakfasts which they serve starting at 7 a.m. and don´t stop until...
item.content:encoded:
Panama Casco Antiguo

“El Barón Rojo” (The Red Baron) is a small café at Calle 4ta and Avenida A, next to Arco Properties.   Brand new spot, so you won`t see the sign out yet! but you`ll see the chairs outside.  Their specialty: wonderful breakfasts which they serve starting at 7 a.m. and don´t stop until 3 p.m.

So far we`ve tried the granola with fruit and yogurt which is served in a very generous bowl and the pineapple juice was in one of those high 1 pint glasses you (well, not sure if “you” but any Panamanian) would link to carnival beer drinking. Loved it! give me that much of fresh pineapple juice anytime!

My next move will be to try the vegetarian big breakfast: two poached free-range eggs on grain toast, homemade hash browns, garlic mushrooms, tomato, spinach and avocado.

item.title: US Embassy, Conservatorio S.A. and Fundacion Calicanto join hands with Panama`s Scouts
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama This past weekend, the US Embassy, Fundacion Calicanto and Casco Viejo developer Conservatorio S.A. joined hands to build and paint a meeting space for Panama`s Scouts at the Santa Familia Community Center in San Felipe, Calle 4ta. This meeting room will allow Troupe No. 3 Casco Viejo to develop its youth program,...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama

This past weekend, the US Embassy, Fundacion Calicanto and Casco Viejo developer Conservatorio S.A. joined hands to build and paint a meeting space for Panama`s Scouts at the Santa Familia Community Center in San Felipe, Calle 4ta.

This meeting room will allow Troupe No. 3 Casco Viejo to develop its youth program, which has grown in the past two years from a small group of ten to thirty.  Some of the kids are starting to enter the “teenage” program, an important continuation that will provide a platform for at risk children, keeping them out of the streets during this difficult part of personal development. The troupe has been funded for years by members of AVACA (Casco Antiguo`s Friend`s and Neighbors Association) and had now grown to the point of needing a space to meet.

About 20 US Embassy volunteers painted side by side with a group over 40 Scouts and volunteers from Fundación Calicanto and private developer Conservatorio S.A. who helped set up the classroom. US Ambassador Phylis Powers had a wonderful time painting with the kids, and at the end a special “wall” was set up for everyone to “sign” it by marking it with their hands and writing their name next to it.

For over six years, Casco Viejo has been an interesting experimental ground for social programs, most of them founded by the private sector.  From successful educational programs for women and children to violence prevention and gang re socialization,  synergy among different NGO`s and the private sector has made true change through small but effective actions possible.  They provide with a sense of continuity that politic- driven changing governments can´t.  The US Embassy has also taken an important interest in supporting some of these programs as their contribution to prevent violence in the country.

For all of them, big thumbs up!

item.content:encoded:

Slideluck Potshow is an art event that joins the community by inviting everyone to  bring a home cooked dish to share and enjoy the art slide show they`ve put together for the occasion. Their first event was two years ago at Arco Chato and was fantastic.

This time, the show will be at Espacio Panama on 2nd Street and A Avenue. The event will cost $15 and all proceeds will go to an ngo that help children with leukemia and cancer.

So write down the date! it is a fun event! Check out their Facebook Page.

When:  November 18th, 2011

Hour: 7 p.m.

Where: Calle 2nda and Avenida A (Espacio Panama)

item.title: Casco Viejo, Never a Dull Moment!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: What is a normal day in Casco Viejo? Still undefined, but I would probably say is one packed with small unusual stuff, little happenings here and there that makes every day a “never a dull moment” life in this eclectic neighborhood. From the absurd to the common, from people filming in the streets for an...
item.content:encoded:
What is a normal day in Casco Viejo? Still undefined, but I would probably say is one packed with small unusual stuff, little happenings here and there that makes every day a “never a dull moment” life in this eclectic neighborhood.   From the absurd to the common, from people filming in the streets for an independent movie (dressed up as who knows what and just walking around) to kids playing “vintage” games like jumping on each other like frogs in the street (or should I say “forgotten games”?).

A neighborhood for the adventurous, artistic soul, Casco Viejo wakes up every day with something for everyone.

item.title: Casa de Rosa, Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Panama, Casco Antiguo On Friday we attended the inauguration of Casa de Rosa, a restored building that used to belong to Rosa Eleta de Prieto back in 1921. The apartments are quite spacious, specially the living rooms! Records show that the original house was built in 1917. However, when they started digging, they found a...
item.content:encoded:
Panama, Casco Antiguo

On Friday we attended the inauguration of Casa de Rosa, a restored building that used to belong to Rosa Eleta de Prieto back in 1921. The apartments are quite spacious, specially the living rooms!

Records show that the original house was built in 1917. However, when they started digging, they found a piece of a “Hornabeque”. An Hornabeque in Spanish is a defensive system that offshore colonial cities used to build back in 1765 – 1769. This one was designed by Colonel Manuel Hernandez, who was sent to the Americas by King Charles III in 1759 to reinforce the security of the back then fortified Panama City. The piece of this wall is shown through a glass floor, and is a witness of a time where this area was nothing but flatland … and a wall.

The apartments are beautiful and will not be for sale… only for rent! While the area is in transition, you`ll be neighbors with the Danilo Perez jazz foundation and Olga Sinclair`s brand new art foundation. Last floor has great water views!

item.title: Panama`s Secret History
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama   Every city has stories hidden under their “cement jungle”. This is the slogan for a History Channel TV Series called “Secret Histories”. A couple of years ago they did an entire episode about Panama, which covers Casco Viejo with a lot of interesting characters. The episode was made for Latin America,...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama

 

Every city has stories hidden under their “cement jungle”.  This is the slogan for a History Channel TV Series called “Secret Histories”.   A couple of years ago they did an entire episode about Panama, which covers Casco Viejo with a lot of interesting characters.  The episode was made for Latin America, so it is all in Spanish. We`ve been trying to find out if they have it in English, but seems that they didn`t.

So, if you speak Spanish, take a look, it is a really well done show.  If you don`t,  we can still give you one great “secret” story to read about: did you know back during the Gold Rush it was a Texas Ranger who was called in to Panama to “put order” in town? Very much a “Billy the Kid”, you might find this little unknown piece of history quite interesting (and revealing) on how things where managed those days: Randolph Runnels.

item.title: Co Working in Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Antiguo Panama You are a creative professional and so far had been working from home, or working for someone but trying to get more “space” for your own work. Renting a shared office is not your style, mostly because you might not relate to the type of businesses next to you and synergy depends...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Antiguo Panama

You are a creative professional and so far had been working from home, or working for someone but trying to get more “space” for your own work.  Renting a shared office is not your style, mostly because you might not relate to the type of businesses next to you and synergy depends on having other creative people around that are on the same (or similar!) wavelength.

Before you go crazy at home (or at work) consider CascoStation!  It is not a “shared office” nor a “virtual office”.  Is a group of independent creative professionals (artists, web, digital, etc) that use CascoStation temporarily to share, network, meet with clients, develop projects.

Located at Calle 5ta & A Avenue, Casco Viejo, fees depend on how much you are there: you can come daily, or just a couple of days or only on Saturdays.

Check out more info and great photos of the facility inside here: COWORKING

Or write Harold (he is fully bilingual, but somehow the website seems to be only in Spanish): work@CascoStation.com

They are also on Facebook and Twitter: Casco Station

Los Del Patio is a small art center in Casco Viejo that provides classes for local children as well as adults. They also have art shows, theater plays and even a small café. Little by little, they`ve been putting together all the tools they need for their work, however they are still missing some stuff and would like to let everyone know in case you happen to have one at home or just want to donate.

Here it is! Los Del Patio Wishlist: it goes from an a/c unit and 40 chairs for their classroom, to art supplies (brush, paint, cardboard, etc.).  You can contact YIYI at their FACEBOOK page.  Or email Arco Properties and we`ll put you in touch: patrizia@arcoproperties.com

item.title: Homage to Casconian: Bruce Quinn
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo Panama The name of Bruce Quinn in Panama is synonym of “theatre” and “musicals”. Since I can recall, Bruce has been an unstoppable dynamo, year after year bringing us beautiful productions, anything from Chicago to Annie and even plays by local writers and singers. A “Zonian” Bruce was born into Panama`s Canal Zone...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo Panama

The name of Bruce Quinn in Panama is synonym of “theatre” and “musicals”. Since I can recall, Bruce has been an unstoppable dynamo, year after year bringing us beautiful productions, anything from Chicago to Annie and even plays by local writers and singers.

A “Zonian”  Bruce was born into Panama`s Canal Zone in the 40`s,  which back in the day meant you had double nationality: Panamanian and American. In the 60`s he starts producing theater shows and more than 200 plays later, he is still running up and down the stage,  guiding young talents, encouraging to give their best.  Several generations have passed by his “school” and are now well known professionals in Panama`s young theater and TV scene.  A beloved grandfather to the genre itself in this country and an example to follow.

A Casconian for many years, Bruce himself is a living history treaty full of juicy facts that I`m sure are a constant inspiration for his work. Last night, the homage at the Canal Museum was set up in three Acts: the formal one where he received as a gift from the Canal Museum a historic tile of the building, then the museum exhibition (which will be open to the public for a month, until the 15th of September) and the “Show of all Shows” where Bruce himself delighted his friends by acting and singing!

So much can be said about him and his experiences that could fill several books. For sure, only a selection of his work filled up a museum floor… and let me tell you, to see all his plays lined up was simply impressive.  What an achievement! Congratulations Bruce!

item.title: Panama: Happy 492th Birthday!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Antiguo, Panama Looking for historic material to write this blog, I found this really cool book (from 1911) with all the gossip about America`s Discovery, founding of the Old Panama City and its later destruction by pirate Henry Morgan, which led to the founding of Casco Viejo, our beloved neighborhood. So, in celebration of...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Antiguo, Panama

Looking for historic material to write this blog, I found this really cool book (from 1911) with all the gossip about America`s Discovery, founding of the Old Panama City and its later destruction by pirate Henry Morgan, which led to the founding of Casco Viejo, our beloved neighborhood.

So, in celebration of Panama`s “roots” here are photos of the city that became one of the most important links during Europe`s conquest of the Americas!

A small poem found on page 23:

“Here the oceans twain have waited

All the ages to be maited, –

waited long, and waited vainly,

Though the script was written plainly;

This, the portal of the sea,

Opens for him who holds the key;

Here the empire of the earth

Waits in patience for its birth.”

James Jeffrey Roche

Happy Birthday Panama!

item.title: Old Panama`s celebration coming up!
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Viejo, Panama   Panamá La Vieja or Old Panama was the first European settlement at the Pacific Ocean. Founded August 15th, 1519 it will be blowing its 492 th candle on Monday! “Panama City” back then was called “Nuestra Señora de la Asunción de Panamá”…. ok, not precisely a 140-character-Twitter-like-easy-to-remember-name, so not surprisingly it...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Viejo, Panama

 

Panamá La Vieja or Old Panama was the first European settlement at the Pacific Ocean. Founded August 15th, 1519 it will be blowing its 492 th candle on Monday!

“Panama City” back then was called “Nuestra Señora de la Asunción de Panamá”…. ok, not precisely a 140-character-Twitter-like-easy-to-remember-name, so not surprisingly it got shortened to just “Panama”.

Shortly after founded, it became the main link for the conquest of Peru.  It grew rich but also had zillion problems such as big fires, health issues (tons of mosquitoes, as they settled in a swampy area…. well, nothing was known yet about what caused all those “tropical fevers”).   The place was also a nightmare to defend, as the bay was easily approachable, a lesson they learned painfully through having to defend the city of several pirate attacks.  And when in 1671 got sacked by Pirate Henry Morgan (it is said that the booty was carried in 195 mules!)  the inhabitants of the city decided they had enough… and moved to Casco Viejo.

item.title: Panama and Cuba: Born a Couple of Months Apart
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Holidays in Cuba evoque sun, guayaberas, music, mojitos and dance. An image of the famous Hotel Nacional, Cuba’s most recognized hotel mixes with glimpses of Havana Vieja and white beaches at Varadero. But few know that Panama and Cuba were sister countries from the beginning, as they were founded almost at the same time:...
item.content:encoded:
Holidays in Cuba evoque sun, guayaberas, music, mojitos and dance. An image of the famous Hotel Nacional, Cuba’s most recognized hotel mixes with glimpses of Havana Vieja and white beaches at Varadero. But few know that Panama and Cuba were sister countries from the beginning, as they were founded almost at the same time: Panamá Viejo in August (1519) and Habana Vieja in November (1519).  And few realize how easy it is to invest in Panama… Cuban Style.

How and why?  first a bit of history since this upcoming Monday the 15th, we celebrate the foundation of Panama Viejo (or Panama La Vieja).  This city which was Spain’s first settlement at the Pacific, was moved after its destruction by Pirate Henry Morgan to Casco Viejo (called interchangeably San Felipe or Casco Antiguo) where gold from South America was sent to Europe by mule through Panama’s dense jungle, then by boat to the mythical Portobelo and from there to Cuba.  Through years of this exchange, Panama and Cuba grew very much alike culturally and architecturally.

When walking around, visitors are often surprised at how much it reminds them of Havana, Cuba.  Children playing everywhere, street music on Fridays (and frankly, all weekend).  Caribbean architecture mixed with Spanish Colonial, French and even Art Deco, reflecting Panama’s cultural makeup in a cozy human scale.  Today, Casco Viejo – one of the most eclectic historic real estate in the region – is being revitalized, hosting the best restaurants, hotels, bars and theatres of Panama City.

 

While owning a piece of Havana might be a challenge, real estate in Casco Viejo  is privately owned, easy to purchase and fully titled. It is already home to a  mixed community of locals and foreigners from all around the globe (Europeans, Americans… Australians!).  With hotels already under construction targeted to different economic niches, the area is about to experience a wave of appreciation. Prices for fully restored properties are half of their renovated peers in Cartagena or San Juan, where they have already felt the benefits of hotels and tourism.

Panama has already positioned itself as the hub of the Americas, with easy connections to the United States, Europe and South America. If you are reading this and might think on checking it out, clear a long weekend and experience it first hand!

Where to Stay in Casco Viejo?

Where to Go in Panama?

How to invest in Casco Viejo…. that one is easy, just contact us!

item.title: 1920`s Elegance Today at Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Antiguo, Panama It used to be the flag ship store of the Benedetti Hermanos back in 1928. The original commercial space at the ground floor had an elegant glass facade that echoed the look and feel of Madison Avenue shops of the day. In the 50`s it was a well known furniture store, the...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Antiguo, Panama

It used to be the flag ship store of the Benedetti Hermanos back in 1928.  The original commercial space at the ground floor had an elegant glass facade that echoed the look and feel of Madison Avenue shops of the day.   In the 50`s it was a well known furniture store, the perfect business to take advantage of such commanding street presence.

Today, with over 400 mt2 of commercial space, Benedetti Hermanos is completely restored and ready once again to draw everyone`s attention in San Felipe.  Located steps away from several high end hotels already under construction (Hotel American Trade, Hotel Herrera, Hotel Plaza Herrera, Hotel Veyra and a Convention Center) and some already open like Las Clementinas, Casa Antigua and Casa del Horno this commercial space is the perfect spot for high end stores, wine stores and  banks.

To learn more: email us at patrizia@arcoproperties.com

item.title: Photographers Invade Casco Viejo

Armed with amazing cameras and tripods, they took photos of everything and anything that passed by, including me and my dog. While I`m sure we ended up as a “study case” at someone`s studio with the generic name “girl...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Antiguo, Panama

A group of photographers sneaked into the night and took over Las Bovedas. Armed with amazing cameras and tripods, they took photos of everything and anything that passed by, including me and my dog. While I`m sure we ended up as a “study case” at someone`s studio with the generic name “girl n`dog” (which could have been taken anywhere), most of the photos where of Las Bovedas itself and the ocean, true tourism “postcards” for Panama and the old city. To imagine the thousands of photos of Casco Viejo that must be flying right now around the world through all these professionals!

item.title: Investment Moving Forward in Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Antiguo, Panama   A client came into our office yesterday and marveled at the thriving activity in Casco Viejo. He pointed out that there are almost no streets in San Felipe that doesn`t have something going on, whether a new business opening or a property under construction. Plaza Herrera, one of the biggest and...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Antiguo, Panama

 

A client came into our office yesterday and marveled at the thriving activity in Casco Viejo.  He pointed out that there are almost no streets in San Felipe that doesn`t have something going on, whether a new business opening or a property under construction.   Plaza Herrera, one of the biggest and most beautiful plazas which was abandoned up until now, is a vibrant “under construction” site.  Located at the center of Casco Antiguo is is destined to become its commercial heart.

Here are some of the commercial projects currently under construction. By no means a complete list!

The original Hotel Herrera, this beautiful property is now being restored.  The property will have less than 20 rooms and a micro brewery at the groundfloor. Fun!

 

 

 

Corner restaurant site under construction. The building will have two commercial spaces set up for restaurants: groundfloor with mezzanine and top floor with an amazing terrace.

 

 

American Trade Hotel: a four building restoration project that will hold an elegant 50 room hotel with restaurant, jazz bar and Casco Viejo`s first “convention center”.

 

 

 

The event space will have capacity to host events up to 800 people.  A perfect place for weddings and banquets.

 

 

 

La Cantina, also under construction, will be a three level restaurant at the entrance of San Felipe. Water views, outdoor and indoor seating. Roof terrace too!

 

 

Ay! Carmela is a restaurant located at 9th Street, San Felipe that opened August 2nd. Wonderful sandwiches, the place has a friendly ambiance with outdoors and indoor seating.

 

 

 

Casa del Horno inaugurated also this week (officially!). The hotel has 8 rooms, a restaurant and a café. Located at B Avenue and 8th street.

It is located at the groundfloor of Casa Antigua, next to Luna`s Castle on 9th Street and BAvenue, just coming up the ramp. The place is cute and has...
item.content:encoded:

Run by Gonzalo, his lovely wife Vani and their partner Patricia Gómez, Ay! Carmela just opened its doors this week in Casco Viejo.  It is located at the groundfloor of Casa Antigua, next to Luna`s Castle on 9th Street and BAvenue, just coming up the ramp.

The place is cute and has great sandwiches!. They`ll open for breakfast, starting at 7:30 a.m. Outdoor and indoor seating.  Welcome Ay! Carmela!

item.title: Organic Grocery Shopping in Casco Viejo, Panama
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: Casco Antiguo, Panama   Panama has slowly gotten into the “organic” wave. Little by little, small farms are getting their connections and productions worked out and they`re reaching Casco Viejo! This past month, I`ve been keeping an eye out for good products and services. Here are my favorites! Culantro Rojo: Season vegetables, goat cheese, cacao,...
item.content:encoded:
Casco Antiguo, Panama

 

Panama has slowly gotten into the “organic” wave.  Little by little, small farms are getting their connections and productions worked out and they`re reaching Casco Viejo!

This past month, I`ve been keeping an eye out for good products and services.  Here are my favorites!

Culantro Rojo: Season vegetables, goat cheese, cacao, borojo juice, marmalade of strange tropical fruits I can`t pronounce but taste great, honey, home made pesto, organic dry beans, organic eggs, goat cheese (wonderful! yummi… ), goat yogurts, organic Duck and even home made soaps.

Once a week they send an email reminding you what they have in store.  They can deliver to your home or you can pick it up at their office in Calle 4ta, Casco Viejo. They are between Arco Properties and Central Avenue.  Contact them at: info@culantrorojo.com

Super Gourmet: Casco`s favorite lunch hangout, they have the basic vegetables (tomatoes, onions, avocado, seasonal fruits), Soy Milk and organic cacao.    They also carry a complete line of coconut oil based beauty products that come from the Caribbean province of Bocas del Toro.  Try the coconut oil with ginger! soaps and more. Location: A Avenue and 6th Street.

Papiro y Yo:   our favorite store for gifts made out of paper and recycling materials have started to take their good “taste” to another level.  Creative new souvenirs involving organic products. The true meaning of “Made in Panama”!.  They are carrying organic honey, black pepper and other spices.  Rosemary soaps, Cinnamon soaps and other beautiful scents.  Location: 4th Street, between Ave. Central and B Avenue. Some of their products have been started to be carried by restaurants such as Caffe Vienna (1st Street and A Avenue).

New Earth Panama: I tried their delivery service this weekend and it was really good.  They don´t base in Casco Viejo (yet!).   They have a wide selection of products, including not only fruit, vegetables and grains, but also  fish, seafood and eggs.  I placed an order Sunday at noon through the website, and they confirmed it by phone shortly after. It showed up at my office Monday morning, featuring a BIG papaya that I thought was going to take half of my fridge (didn`t I ask for the “medium” size one? … yes you did… this is it….was the answer).  Loved it!

Here is the contact:  José David Nieto  Cel.: (507)67319805/ jdn@newearthpanama.com / info@newearthpanama.com

item.title: A Restored 1899 Home For Sale at Casco Viejo
item.dc:creator: patrizia
item.description: One of the things I enjoy the most in Casco Viejo is the fact that each home is truly different from the one next to it. There are no identical twins here, no “copy – paste” and each one has a history of its own. Casa Vidal , our featured home for sale, is the...
item.content:encoded:
One of the things I enjoy the most in Casco Viejo is the fact that each home is truly different from the one next to it. There are no identical twins here, no “copy – paste” and each one has a history of its own.

Casa Vidal , our featured home for sale, is the perfect example. The first public deed of the house dates from August 12th, 1899 and certifies that the owner was Doña Teresa Arosemena de Vidal, known as the Widow Vidal.  Back then, Panama was not even Panama, but the “isthmus” of Panama and it belonged to Colombia!

Today, Casa Vidal has been developed into one of the few Casco Viejo`s single family townhouse.  The contrast between the house`s Caribbean style upper facade with the heavier groundfloor made out of colonial stone and carved in a French style illustrates the architectural eclecticism for which Casco Antiguo is known.

Abandoned for nearly half a century, Casa Vidal`s stone and mortar ground floor stood strong, but her wooden fasade and structure needed to be completely rebuilt. This provided the design team with the opportunity to take advantage of the interior`s great volumes and natural light.  The double height living room brings a special feeling to the main area, while the thickness of the walls bring a cozy, intimate feeling to the house.

The master bedroom allows privacy, light and cross ventilation. Casa Vidal`s ground floor opens onto a walled garden, providing the opportunity for a private den, office or guest bedroom.

But without a doubt, Casa Vidal`s most unusual features is the rooftop deck with its plunge pool and stunning views of Panama City, the Pacific Ocean and the Paseo Esteban Huertas.

Price: $860,000

Area: 376.16 mt2

3 Bedrooms, 3 1/2 Bathrooms

(Under Construction)
